reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first StarMade Experience:
1st-2nd hours:
I get on the server (redshift). I am so damn overwhelmed by the cool spawn and spaceships docked there. I have no idea of what to do, so I request help from a fellow player. One thing leads to another, and I am now in this guy's faction. its just the guy, his friend, and me. He surprisingly has about six ships, 2 for mining, one with a jump drive, a few fighters, and some other huge ship with unknown purpose,also a space station orbiting a terraformed planet. Guy teaches me the basics, and then logs off. You can not blame me for wanting to try out the stuff. First I try building my own ship, a core, a power supply and a thruster, and I realize the ship is simple and fast. I land on the planet. I forget to press shift. ship flies off even with me getting out of it. I'm stranded in the planet. SHEEEEIIIIT. I start mining blocks, and build a pilar trying to reach the space station. I am successful, and get back on.
3rd Hour:
I now am familiar with the basic controls of the game (I took a while to get used to the controls of this one). I am curious, so I decide to take the warpship for a spin. The jumpdrive jumps about 8 sectors per jump. I start charging and jumping all over the universe,the setting is relaxed, I'm listening to some slow trance,and I am actually having a lot of fun exploring. Suddenly I see another station. I should dock there" I thought. As I arrive near the foreign station my systems begin to fail

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On my daily game browsing, I was looking for anything interesting. I came across this game. This is one of the coolest games I have ever played. Some people say this is a Space Engineers clone...it is not. And I am sure (Idk who or why) someone has called this a Minecraft clone...GOD no. (It's in space, come on now.) I will break this up into different sections, with a TL;DR at the end, as well as a section for those who read the whole thing! Thank you.

ONE MORE THING: The demo unlocks the whole game for free. The developer said it will stay that way until it goes out of early access, and that buying it is mainly just to support development.

Why it is awesome:

1. Customization. You can build any kind of ship you want. A ship for transporting things, a ship for mining, a fighter, a massive battle ship, a mining ship with salvage beams (Those are beams that mine for you. SO you shoot at something, it being an ore, rock, or even parts of another ship or station) or any combination of all. (This is not all, of course)

2. Fighting. The fighting is incredible and fun, and fast paced action. It is like a Star Wars battle. You can have your fleet of 20 ships versus another player's fleet of 20 ships or against Space Pirates, or in single player, you versus a bunch of pirates (Idk yet if you can have computer controlled fighting allies in singleplayer) The complex weapons systems are for a whole other part of the review.

3. The complex weapons systems. There is the basic cannons, lasers, and missiles, and they are fun and damaging. You can make the cannons and any other weapon touch each other to make 1 very damaging weapon, or you can space them out to have many of that weapon firing at once. Here is where it gets complex. You can combine weapons. *SPOILER HERE* So you can combine the cannon and the missile to make a shotgun like weapon on your ship. *SPOILER END* Cool right? And there are over 80 combinations (so I have read). So lots of fun to be had with weapons. (And don't be afraid to stack them up a ton. If you have the weapons available, and the power available, make some crazy weapons systems.)

4. NPCs. This is where Space Engineers is lacking so far, but will have them in the future. There are, like I said, Space Pirates. They have killed me many times. But if you have the power and the numbers, fight them back and steal from them and you shall be granted rich reward...so I assume. There are also NPCs at some shops.

5. Shops. You can go to a shop and buy anything in the game. You need a lot of money for many things, but you can get a lot of money fairly easy with the right knowledge of what is really valuable, like ores and glass. (More fun with shops later in the review)

6 Space Stations. You can do a lot of the same stuff with stations that you can do with ships. I am not sure what it has weapons wise, but I am sure there are good things with that. I know there are turrets. Automated turrets and controllable I think. Very customizable. To make a space station though, you need 1,000,000 credits. Which tbh, isn't that bad. I saw one guy get like 2 million credits from selling a bunch of salvaged (collected) glass. And with a faction you can claim a station as yours and make it invulnerable to damage and stealing. It also makes any docked ships invulnerable too. So griefers aren't a problem with this HAHA!

7. Factions. You can make a faction and build on faction points with players to join it (Idk if npcs can join or not), taking over sectors and systems, defeating enemies, and so on. With a faction you can claim a space station and make it invulnerable to damage and stealing. And you can claim a whole system as your territory. Again, there are 128 x 128 x 128 (I think) sectors in a system, so that is a TON of space as yours. With a faction, you can also make your own shops! You can price items how you want, decide what is on your market, and sell things to other players, and maybe even npcs. (You may not need a faction, you may only need a space station to make a shop. I can't remember) And with a faction you can keep growing your territory until you take over everything MUAHAHAHAHAHHAHA! (Not even kidding though)

8. Build mode/Advanced build mode. Who doesn't love a good build mode for easy ship/station construction? With regular build mode you can do all the basic stuff like placing/deleting blocks, flying, sped up flying, connecting blocks and groups, and all that stuff. With advanced build mode, you can use symmetry (For precise building), copy/pasting/saving pieces of ships or stations as templates, mass building with placing up to 10 blocks in every axis at a time (So you can build a 10 x 10 x 10 cube with one click), rotating blocks, and a few other things. So very fun and easy to use. Makes for easy building of a massive ship.

9. Jump drives/Warp gates. *SPOILER HERE* The jump drives and warp gates are a great way to get around fast, but you need alot of power. With a jump drive, you can jump" up to 8 sectors away. With warp gates
date: (I think) you can warp up to 128 sectors away. So very convenient.\n\n10. Asteroids

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game to any and everybody that likes Sci-Fi Space themed action games and also has a knack for Minecraft. You'll find that you can literally do ANYTHING of your choosing in this game, and honestly of all the alpha games I have ever played, this feels almost like something beyond a complete game, with the exception of a few bugs. A warning to someone that just starts this game: You'll NEED to look up tutorials, and you'll NEED to use the wiki. (I recommend Starmadepedia). I'll summarize my expierience thus far.

Started Playing Game
Did Tutorial
Built a Crappy Ship
Combines a post I saw on steam + Some new found knowledge and made a Mining Ship
Spent upwards of 2 hours mining a small area of asteroids
Sold the minerals to the local shop
Bought a faction module to find a place to settle and claim
Bought a Space Station
Claimed a System after building a small station
Made a goal to be able to mine Asteroids in seconds
Did more Mining
More Mining
Upgraded Ship to the point it could easily eat an asteroid in a minute or less
Read a Post that said you could blow up planets
Made the ambitous goal to mine away entire planets and then blow them up (Or vice versa)
More Mining
Setup factories that were super efficient (You can increase factory outputs with Factory Enchancers)
Built a whole bunch of parts to add on to my system
Learned about Cannon Computers to Salvage Computers
Upgraded my system
Could now mine entire planets, but not destroy them
Learned about Nuke Missiles
Made a system with a Pulse Module Slaved to a Missile Module for Nukes compiling a 2.3k block array
Learned that my nuke used way to much power
Did a bunch of swearing
Tripled my power storage and reactor setup to accomadate my nuke setup
More swearing because it couldn't accomadate the setup
Doubled the reactor and power setup again, along with adding Lasers and Cannons
Finally was able to launch nukes
Blew up a world
Lagged out the Server
Got back on Server
Started raiding a nearby Pirate Station
Slowly built up ship till it could take out Pirate Station
Started helping newbies with newbie issues
Blew up another world and mined all its contents to impress said newbies


This was about 2 days worth a play time total,  and I did not regret a single second of it :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Once upon a time...no, wait, never mind.  I'm still bulding the U.S.S Defiant.

StarMade is a block-buildy game In Space!  The best way to explain it to people is, to start by imagining MineCraft.  Now, take your awesome castle, and put thrusters and guns on it.  That's StarMade...only, it's not quite as engaging, even about seven months after my original review.

Some changes have happened, including a price hike to $14.99.  Thus, I'm taking the extra hours I've played in the intervening months into account, and doing a re-review.  Has it improved?  Well...you will see.

What Works
First, the visuals have improved greatly from my prior review, and the game overall looks pretty nice.  You can build some neat ships and stations.  The Pentas/Tetras/Corners allow for somewhat blocky re-builds of your favorite Sci-Fi ships, or your own custom creations.  Some recent texture updates from the developers have made good ships look even better!

Performance is also improved to the point where the game is at least playable on medium-grade machines.  This was a critical problem for me in my previous review, but the developers deserve credit for working to make the game behave more efficiently.  Good job there!

The UI has improved a lot in seven months too.  There are some issues with resizing individual windows, but the game is easily understandable via the UI, and gives you most of the tools you need to build ships, which is the game's primary mechanic.  The secondary mechanic, shooting stuff with your ship, is also well-accounted for, with shield, structural HP, and armor HP being presented well.  There are some placeholders about, as this game is still in development, but progress is being made.  I'm sure seven months in the future, the UI will be a lot better than it already is, and I look forward to that.

What Doesn't Work
Before I get to anything heavy, I have to talk about the crafting system.  The crafting system is OK in a survival setting, and some much-needed tuning has happened...but ultimately, to make a decent ship, you need a lot of blocks, because in this game, bigger ship = better.  There's additional problems with that that we will get to, but the crafting system as it stands actually hampers the process of doing the main thing that you should be doing in a game about building starships: actually building starships.  To solve this, the crafting UI and system needs a pretty massive interface revamp, and some thought should be taken to all the 'wasted' blocks about, things like plantlife that could be leveraged to make more interesting builds.  It's as if the developers started off by copying MineCraft, then at some point decided, oh yeah
date: the point of this game is to make ships!"\n\nNext

So first thing I do when I get this game is jump onto multiplayer.
Servers kinda quiet, so I make a tiny shuttle ship and head to the nearest planet.
Planet bored me eventually so I mined it out and made a bigger ship.
At this point random guy starts talking to me, one thing leads to another.
I'm now flying his friend back to their home planet after he got stranded on a planet.
More stuff happens, we make a faction.
I start work on gigantic battleship thing with missile turrets the size of skyscrapers. (Ships can get really big in this game)
Notice the pirate station nearby has been shooting down my friends and I engage with my battleship in an epic fight to destroy it.
Pirate station blows up, but not before hitting my bridge with a missile while my shields were down, resulting in a spectacular explosion.
Ship that took 1 day to build = gone.
Me and friends log off the server to join some others and get into more space related mishap.

10/10 Would blow my time on going down with an expensive battleship again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutly  epic,  the best way for me to review this for you is to guide you through my first few real life days in the game.

Day 1:  I started by myself built a ship core added thrusters, cannons and and mining beams mined asteroids for a few hours and with those resources built/bought shields for my ship. with my shields up and cannons ready I go to the nearest pirate station... After spending about 5 minutes with red beams flashing everywhere around my ship and me firing to no effect on the station I decide to close the range... cause i thought my cannons where out of range... I must say the shield hit effects were epic and they were the last things i saw before my ship imploded. that ended my first day.

Day 2:  I play with my friend with a few of his mates and we build a small planetary hideout kitted out with basic factory and power generation capabilities along with a bit of a decorative sense. we decide to build a space station and begin work on ceaser station.

Day 3:  After an all nighter building our station it is finally completed We look upon our basic station with pride it had an internal medium hanger bay and a small exterior bay. little did we know that while we were building our lttle station the others had been amassing a fleet. Blissfully unaware we continue expanding our station. making a cool interior command room, hanger observation room, a working red alert system with logic blocks and a nice room to watch the planet we were orbiting from.

Day 4:  My friend and I are discussing on skype what our plans are for the station today as we connect to the server. We decide to build another (larger) hanger bay and a med bay. While im working on setting up the docking zones for the large hanger my friend decides to go out in our mining ship to replenish our rapdily depleting supply of money and materials. While he is out I notice 4 new contacts appear on my screen all of a sudden, blissfully unaware I check my navigation bar to see what the new contacts are. Bunny Buster, Major Pain, Meals on Thrusters and 1701. I wondered if they wanted to trade with us (we had just set up our shop) so I asked them if they would like to dock... the response i got was not the one i hoped for... One ship fired what must of been over a hundred missiles all of which quickly turned to face the station and our fighter craft and begun to speed towards us. Realising we were under attack I screamed for reinforcements from my friend and ran for the fighter hoping to get into it and fly off to allow its shield to recharge. The first volley of missiles totaly obliterated that hope, I watched as the core (all that survived of my fighter) spun past overheating. And decided to do the last thing that I could, I ran for the control center deep in the center of our station hoping that the attackers would get bored before they shot through all the intervening rooms and armour blocks. Upon reaching the control room I played my last card... I activated the Red alert system we had spent half an hour setting up. Immediatly all the lights in our station turned off... and .5 seconds later red ones turned on to replace them. That done I activated the build block so I could watch them destory my work. The ship that fired all the missiles was now steaidly pouring barrages of missiles into the station which while not having much dammage lowered our shields slowly. A second ship oppened up with Ion beams (as i latter found out) which almost instantly stripped the remaining shields from our station. The remaining two ships then closed and each fired a single missile one they had coloured green the other red. I thought that my station could easily withstand two missiles I mean it had surrived hundreds so far... how wrong I was each missile detonated with all the fury of a nuclear weapon punching giant holes in our beutiful home (turns out they had mergered pulse and missile blocks to make these missiles). I watched on as they fired the seconds volley and counted the seconds till  my command centre exploded around me. and so ended my 4th day.

Day 5:  I joined up with the  ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s  AWESOME GUYS who destroyed my station so i could learn their ways... and boy did I learn lots ;-)

This Game lets you do SO MUCH, every weapon can be merged with other weapons to create different effects e.g cannon to cannon to create a rapid fire cannon (good for missile defence if mounted on a turret) Pulse to missile makes the lock on nukes. Missile to Missile make swarm missiles which independantly lock on to hostile targets. There are jump drives, cloaking devices (which I recently figured out how to use) Scanners, Radar jammers And more. This game is great and getting better

10/10 strongly suggest you buy it! If you do and your interested in multiplayer please tell me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't be fooled by the number of hours played on Steam. I've been a longtime supporter of StarMade, and have played hundreds of hours before the Steam release.

StarMade is a sci-fi voxel based sandbox game.

If I had to pick a game that it feels similar to, I would say Minecraft. There is a comparable level of addictivness, as well as a somewhat greater level for truly amazing creations.

Simply put, StarMade is really, really good. In it's current state, the schine team are working hard on bugfixes, rebalancing, and adding awesome new content. There will be builds that change the balance of ships, so you will need to redo some ship systems entirely.

---------------

+ building is simple and easy to master

+ there is crafting, so you can start with nothing on the surface of a planet and work your way up

+ in-depth faction system

+ community makes some fantastic things

+ logic system has unlimited potential (like redstone but better)

+ visually stunning

+ game is made for multiplayer, and handles it just as well as singleplayer

+ constant optimization and bugfixes from devs

---------------

- Not a finished product

- Still in development, there will be bugs, there will be changes you won't like immediately. You just need to deal with it and be patient.

---------------

FEATURES:

> Practically infinite universe

> Ship building, station building

> Solar systems

> Suns, Planets, Asteroids

> Black holes and wormholes

> Warp Gates and Jump Drives

> Logic system

> Factions

> others I can't think of right now

PLANNED/UPCOMING FEATURES:

> Creatures

> Quests

> Better Ai

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game for awhile before it hit steam so my hours might be a bit skewed.  I'm gonna list some features I like below, and as the game grows I will add onto this list, and other things.

-Liked Features ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-People don't move or skit around when on ships. This is a big one, and a lot of space building games have players glitching or even getting stuck in walls becuase they don't treat the ship as a anchor.

-Much like an open world game. If you see it you can probably go to it. This game blows my mind on how expansive it is. You see that red dot in the distance? Thats a star, you can go there. That yellow dot? Another star. Seriously this game is crazy with this stuff and it blows my mind.

-Populated servers. If you haven't played on a server yet do it. Great expierence.

-Movable Asteroids. Its just fun to push them around, or even use them for cover.

-Block Variety. This is another big one for me becuase its real nice to have a large list of blocks just to build nice looking ships with.

-Advanced & Basic building. You can go very advanced with building in this game to get the most efficiency out of ships, or you can go basic, and get a alright ship.

-Logic Systems. Probably one of the best things a building game can include, absolutely amazing!

-Planets. You can even orbit them, or mine them out! Seriously planets are amazing they even have there own axis of rotation.

-Wormholes. You can travel throughout the galaxy on wormholes.

-Pirates. While they variety is lacking in the base vanilla game, you can add in your own Custom Pirates into the game.

-PVP. Great expierence this one its fun watching two giant frigates battle it outside a planet.

-Weapon Combinations. Probably one of my favourite features. Being able to combine a Rocket with a Cannon to make a shotgun is just the best.

-Breaching. It was done alright fun as all hell though.

-Shipyards. Absolutely amazing. Although I don't use it much its really fun to see a friend dock his        ship into our base.

- Great Tutorial. Gotta say helped me out a bunch!

~Developers + Support Team~ --------------------------------------------------------------------

- While I am not a developer my self I will say that they probably have one of the best support teams and dev's I have seen in early acess. I reported a bug about a wormhole spawning in my spawn when I first got the game and within a day it was on the bug tracker and my issue fixed! The developers also keep frequent updates, and are amazingly active on the forums.

- The demo is the full game. This is amazing for early access you are giving players a chance to play the game, and see if they want to support you! Great move on the creators.
- If you are gonna do early acess this is how you do it right!


~Servers~ -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- My expierence with servers have been fun. If you are gonna play starmade you absolutely gotta do it in a server. The game normally feels empty in singleplayer but in multiplayer servers usually add there own custom pirates, and tons of players populate the game! Seriously give this a shot.

~Community~
- Probably one of the friendliest communities I have ever met! Seriously they are a major help and I suggest you visit the forums here.  http://starmadedock.net/forums/ "

~Some bad things~ -------------------------------------------------------------------------
A review isn't a review without some bad things. The game is still early acess so I won't really put bug complaints here.
(This list may grow)
- Windows block out some things. Not sure if this is a bug or intended
date: but you cannot see the sun
hoursPlayed:
and missiles through certain pieces of glass. If this was intended maybe instead of blocking out all particles like that you can just dim them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BUY THIS GAME.

I'm writing this review at the end of 2014, and I must say that StarMade turned out to be a bit of a dark horse contender for my personal GOTY (and that's going up against amazing games like Shadow of Mordor, DA: I, and Endless Legend). I've had more fun with it than I ever had with Minecraft, despite the obvious similarities between the two games. I find myself thinking about StarMade when I'm at work, plotting out new ship designs and planning raids on other factions. I cannot recommend this game highly enough.

So what's the appeal? Why is StarMade so great?

For me, the answer is that it fulfills the promises of games like Space Engineers, Eve, STO, and even legendary franchises like the X series. It is one of the first sci-fi games I've ever played that strikes a perfect balance between space combat, ground combat, ship design, strategy, and a vibrant in-game economy. The game is still early-access, and this is somewhat obvious at times (particularly on planets, which currently do not spawn pregenerated structures or mobs), but there's just so damned much to DO - particularly if you're playing online - that you'll rarely care.

One of the most appealing aspects of the game is ship and station design. You'll start off floating in the void of space, somewhere near the center of a proc-gen galaxy. You have 25, 000 credits and some basic building components, which can be used to make a large fighter, or, more likely, a small, all-purpose vessel. Whatever you decide, every single aspect of the design is up to you. Want a donut-shaped ship? Do it! Want to fly Moya, the Galactica, or the USS Enterprise? It'll be expensive, but it's totally doable. Want turbolifts between decks, drone racks, or a tractor beam? Build the right components and you can install them anywhere you want on your ship. Be careful though, because every block you place serves an important purpose - and every block can be destroyed. This means you can lose gravity partway through a fight, potentially jettisoning your friends into the void of space. Or perhaps the logic that controls your turbolifts will go down, trapping you on the command deck until repairs can be made. StarMade is, IMO, the most complex and well-executed science-fiction simulator available, with its infinite possibilities offering countless moments of drama, terror, and triumph.

I could keep raving about how great this game is, but, well, I kinda want to play it instead. I HIGHLY recommend that anyone who's a fan of sci-fi or sandbox games give the game a whirl. Trust me, the $10 or so that they're asking for is an absolute steal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Arms Race in Space
It’s been about two hours of furious clicking, and I still haven’t finished this battlecruiser. I am so focused on getting this done so that I can as soon as possible take it into outer space and blow the crap out of my rivalling faction’s outpost that lies 9 solar systems away. I must prove like many other factions in StarMade, that the “ACE Pirates” is a faction that are to be taken seriously and I am sure that when this battlecruiser is done, they will never even consider launching a missile at even the weakest of our mining ships.
StarMade is all about building spaceships and continuously upgrading them as time flies by while having such a blast. Whenever one thought that one’s interstellar battlecruiser was too big, an hour or two later they will not think so anymore. StarMade creates this need, this addiction to keep on destroying, keep on mining and to keep on building that spaceship of yours that you will brag about to all the people on the server – until someone with some space dreadnought that is twice your size shoves a missile down your throat. When such things happen, StarMade emotionally attached you to that ship, and it emotionally attached you to making that ship beat someone else’s. StarMade makes you think of your spaceship as your children, you want the best out of them and you keep on encouraging them – or even force them to be better that others. That’s what happens when you get this thought; “how shall I build this weapon system to one-shot that guy?”.
At first StarMade would seem very similar to Minecraft – which it is in both its aesthetics and fundamental gameplay. They are both games based on blocks and building. But apart from that it has what Minecraft lacked and made me stuck to the game ever since, namely to be able to build space ships. Not only are the textures so much sharper, and the building materials come in different shapes apart from cubes, but the scale of StarMade is just outstanding. Robin Promesberger spent a decade to code the engine for it and runs so well on even low end pcs. With this you soar the universe, explore millions of different planets, solar systems and galaxies. There is not one world, but hundreds to explore – all in one game!
If you thought space was lonely and think that it’ll be like that in StarMade, I’m sorry but you thought wrong. StarMade’s multiplayer is a fantastic experience of interacting, trading, obliterating and befriending your fellow astronauts in this vast universe of space. Not only is it fun to mine and survive in space alongside them, but joining a faction by teaming up and creating a coalition can be just as exciting. A fully established faction will sometimes be forced to operate in such a way that is almost as complex as modern day politics! For example, a leader that divides certain members to either build, produce blocks, fight or mine. Mine where? When? How? With what? These are all fundamental questions that must be solved within the faction, forcing the players themselves to figure out what’s best for them and for the faction so that they can stand out as a better faction. This is StarMade’s multiplayer experience, which is both unique and enjoyable for the casual to hardcore gamer.
I mentioned continuously upgrading your spaceship and how this hooks you onto the game. To be able to continuously upgrade your ship by adding more modules, more shields, more guns, you have more or less no limits opposed to other scifi shooting games. Your ship depends all on how well you can plan, how well you choose to get resources, and of course how well you design your ship with all these resources you get. Much like the modpacks for Minecraft such as tekkit and feedthebeast, you can build huge factory complexes. In StarMade these are the essential and fundamental parts for wrecking space scrubs in the universe. It takes a long time to get a hang of it, and there is quite a steep learning curve, but you’ll eventually understand the game, and when you do you can do anything you ever wished to do in in space. The part of StarMade that I find most satisfying is when you explode someone’s ship with a missile whilst piloting the spacecraft made of all those resources which you collected and strived hard to turn into modules in your factory complex. It is very amusing to watch the guy’s dead ship drift away for you to take.
Like more or less everything in this universe, there has to always be the downsides. StarMade unfortunately lacks many sounds for certain parts of the game and gives a less immersive feel. Currently the game has a very limited AI simulation, which means that playing the single player mode will feel very lonely. However this can be quickly solved by hopping on to the first multiplayer server in the conveniently placed server list that exists in the launcher. StarMade also lacks a proper third person view perspective, something I and probably many other people think is a natural view point in games.
But for being in alpha, that is quite alright, and the gameplay itself is outstanding and addictive to say the least. StarMade is about building stuff, and sometime later blow stuff up with that stuff. The intense multiplayer creates the competitiveness to progress with designing your ships, and forces this competitiveness to go on. And in the process, forces you to blow up one another in this blocky arms race in space.

The Good
+ Infinite universe,
+ Smooth immersive multiplayer,
+ Well established ship building system
+ Rewarding progression

The Bad
- Lack of AI simulation
- No third person view
- Few sounds.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't let my paltry game play time fool you, I've played at least a hundred hours of this game prior to it coming to steam. It was great. Sure, it is technically in the development phase even now, but if you are curious of whether to purchase this game or not, I would have to say it is likely worth the buy considering the following:

1. Final version will likely be much more expensive, so buy it now to support it's development and get it cheap!

2. Despite the level of development, there is so much to do. Seriously, people are still posting versions of famous starships rebuilt for starmade while others create their own original ships.

3. The community is fantastic! If you have the ability to, you should try setting up a server for you and your friends.

Lastly, many of the complaints I have heard of this game are technical in nature and have been already fixed as of this review. There is only one complaint I have worth mentioning and that is the fact that the system requirements are probably a little higher than listed here. I have a good setup beyond what is required here, but I have to turn down the settings to play this game without issue. I do not believe this game to be as poorly optimised as minecraft, but it definitely can slow down or screw up if you do not alter the settings. Even so, this flaw can be ignored as this game is already becoming a nearly perfect addition to the indie game market.

Definitely a must own for any creative mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started off loving Starmade...then we broke up. Now I spend time thinking about maybe giving it a another shot. I got into the game just after the big graphical re-boot having played Minecraft for years and checking out every voxel based, procedurally generated game I could find. I trolled Greenlight and found many wanna be contenders but Starmade impressed me with it's vision of what it wants to be. Like any relationship we fall in love with what could be, an ideal, sometimes a projection we place onto the other. I am love with what Starmade is trying to be, but has not yet become.

I lost interest for awhile when the docking update changed how turrets and ships dock. I was having a blast using the quirky old system to make a wide range of ships. The new system looks great and will solve many foibles and allow for a great variety of new designs. Just like with the Minecraft updates I got to enjoy a new game play each time Notch added something. Starmade is developing much the same way but because of it's own ambition each major update is quite disruptive. I have seen other early access wallow aimlessly, become abandoned or run off the rails in development. Starmade is doing none of these things. The danger, as I see it, is that Starmade may have trouble fulfilling it's grand ambitions.

Yes this game has a learning curve and I had fun riding that curve. This is the gold-standard for a complex game. If the learning is fun; success, if it is tedious; go play a game more suited to your short attention-span. A simple game is easy to learn and may become boring. A game with depth and possibilities is going take time to master but will remain engaging.

In it's current state (shipyards just released) Starmade is a very solid, playable early access game. There is a smattering of enemies to keep you improving your ship designs. There is no story arc yet but the ship-building is very polished. The Devs have built a proper foundation for an amazing game. It remains to be seen if they can build an engaging experience onto their ground-breaking mechanics while maintaining balance.

Look elsewhere for the hate, I'm going to tell you what I love.

>Design matters. Where you put modules and how you protect your ship will really make a difference. Lots of room for tactics, countermeasures and cool systems. My first death in the game was a suicide. I designed anti-personnel pulsers in the airlock. Two passes and you are still ok, the third pass: you're dead. (You can come in, look around and leave safely or... linger and die.) I died testing the system and laughed my ♥♥♥ off.

>If you can dream it up you can build it. The first major ship I built was a salvage craft. I designed it to rescue shipwrecks. It was big and turned like a pig but fast and survivable. (I used it for daring rescue of a huge ship that got cored by pirates. It was an epic mission that left massive chucks missing from the old Flat-top but both vessels made it home intact. WooHoo)

One of my favorites is the Tholian Enervater: a spider-themed hunter-killer. By design this craft can pursue a small fighter, slow it down using (web) multiple tractor beams (locking it in the crosshairs), rob it of power using (venom) an electro-mcGuffin ray and finally kill it. The theme of the spider worked both visually and tactically. Very Cool, good job Devs.

I decided to make a Whale-ship that could swallow a pirate-craft whole and then eat it. It worked just as I had hoped. (Unfortunately collisions are unavoidable)

I have stealth designs, a 'Tuttle-craft' for repairs, a surveyer/scout, a carrier/salvager, a mining ship with a huge beam.  = ]  Racing has just been introduced so now 'Tuning' will be a part of designing an efficient racer.

> Hey, it's fun to fly too. Never mind the awesome build mode with simple and powerful symmetry & mirroring to reduce keystrokes... this is a very good space cockpit interface. Starmade features a huge number of elements introduced by previous space games but incorporates them well, often getting better results than its predecessors. It may not have the graphical grandeur of Klingon Academy but the systems controls are simple and easy to use in combat. After narrowly escaping from battle and badly damaged, I was able to reconfigure my systems and piece two non-functional weapons into one cobbled together mess of a gun (without going into build-mode). As I limped home I felt like Scotty, under an instrument panel with sparks flying, griping to the ham fisted captain who got us into this mess in the first place (oh, wait...that's me).
Dog fighting is still a bit slow and not very dynamic with the current AI. I hope for more variation in their tactics besides Send more guys".  Multiplayer servers often have custom pirates so there is lots of room for variety.

>Potential. There's that dirty word again. With human crews for opponents in a more populated (by NPCs) world this game could be epic on a level beyond the average tired space-shooter game. It already has nailed the galactic map

Do you want this game?I'll just go straight to the point.. Go download the demo, play it for free and decide for yourself, but don't forget to sleep.

Cons:
There are alot of typos in the game... Not that I should complain about typos...
Some stuff still have missing explenations.
I hear there are a few bugs.. Somewhere.
I can't really play this game smoothly on my Intel HD family graphics card containing craptop.
There are enough settings in the game/server launcher to overwhelm the average user.

Pros:

The game has a lot of fancy features that results in even more fancy player made content
Your creativity is your limit.

Epic building and crafting system.
Epic logic system.
Epic!

The dev team seems to value user input highly. The community has a say!
Its still in alpha, so most of the cons will disappear over time while the ammount of fancy features will grow.
I recommend this game to:
Sandbox enthusiasts

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starmade is everything you want in an epic Sci-Fi space builder sim, minus the shiny graphics and story.

1. Have an actual avatar 1st and 3rd person view, not just the inside of a cockpit
2. Build your ship/station/home world/mech in Creative or Survival modes
3. Create your faction/empire/rebel fleet
4. Travel from space to planet surface and back without load screens
5. Massive Universe...planets/sectors/solar systems/multiple galaxies...you will die of old age before exploring it all
6. Single player or Join one of many Worldwide Multiplayer Servers PVE/PVP/RP
7. Simple or complex Builds, your choice. With indepth logic blocks and functions for the dedicated builder
8. Advanced build mode with adjustable quantity line/plane/cube function, multi axis symmetry build, rotation etc.
9. Blueprints for saving creations, allowing you to respawn, trade, download from or upload to the community site
10. Pre-existing NPC enemies and  AI modules so you can create your own enemies/allies

...There is so much to this game that you really just need to try it. The possibilities are almost endless for those with a healthy imagination.

Starmade is often compared to Minecraft graphically, though it has a much greater selection of block types available. Of course cubes are a given, it is voxel based afterall, but with wedges, corners and their variants your builds can be very sleek. This is the game you should graduate to when you get bored of Minecrafts limitations.
If you simply can not deal with anything less than cinematic style realistic graphics then this game is likely not for you. Try out Empyrion or Space Engineers, both great games, but the trade off is you sacrifice the scope of the game environment.
Sorry fans of Mass Effect and Half Life, but if you are looking for a deep engaging story with fully realized characters and plot, this is not your game.  But if you want to let your imagination loose and create your own story, your own universe alone or with friends then Starmade might be your flavour.

You will spawn into a universe with some inventory to get you going and a limitless expanse of space stretching out before you.
If your first reaction is to look for someone to tell you what to do next, go back to the Steam Store and keep hunting, this is not your game.
But if you see that epic expanse, and excitement fills your heart with the desire to explore, build and test the limitations of your imagination....welcome to the family!
Basically put.
When you were a child, if you saw a cardboard box and had a million ideas of what you could do with it and not one of them included storage, you will love Starmade.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: I only play this game seriously in multiplayer.

This game had me hooked from the moment I saw it released on steam. I had no prior knowledge to its existance, and I wish I had. The prospect of freely being able to build my own ship, and on top of that, exploring an almost infinite number of galaxies and systems, was one of the one things I have been searching for in a game.

The good:
The game runs like a dream, due to its blocky, basic style, yet looks great while doing so.
Exploring the initial galaxy you spawn in is a blast, flitting between systems, mining for resources and credits, trying to work up enough money to repair that station you found, or to even build your own station from scratch, and exploring the mysterious wormholes that spawn in various locations in the galaxy
Ship combat is a blast, there ae multiple weapons systems, upgrades, and combinations to use to your advantage. Want a huge flagship that fire seeking rockets that move faster than any ship built? Sure thing! You want a tiny scout ship with the laser cannon capacity to rip apart said flagship with a few well placed shots? Doable!
Warp drives take alot of the time out of flying at a constant speed of 75 kmph (max speed in my singleplayer games for some reason.)
The plane setting ability allows for perfectly symmetrical building, perfect for making models of famous ships, like the sloppy Battlecruiser I spent hours on. Building in itself is also fun, as you get to explore what possibilities you have with weapons and defensive systems, along with the logic blocks they've added in. I'm still exploring the destructive capabilities of certain weapons themselves.

The gray areas:
Generating a planet takes ALOT of computing power, and my poor little Dell ♥♥♥♥♥ itself trying. Get a better PC" yes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is still in alpha, let alone Early access, but I will put my experience to your service.

Overview:
This game is a voxel-based space sandbox with a bunch of original content.
In this game, you can build ships, and fully customize it with the hundreds of blocks at your disposition.
If you feel like taking a true challenge, you can go on and build a space station.
The game includes factions, and faction battles. Factions have absolutely no player capacity limit. You can easily end up with five hundred factionmates with you.

Now, let's talk about the pros and cons.

PROS:
- Infinite procedurally generated space universe, countless galaxies, special stars, derelict stations... so much content to explore.
- Ships are fully customizable, and can get really accurate thanks to the advanced building mode at your disposition.
- No size limit, feel like building a 400 megatons titan ship ? Feel free to do so, this game doesn't restrict you one bit.
- Full multiplayer support.
- Full controller support.
- Developpement team pays huge regard to community opinion. You are the key to a better StarMade.
- Totally functional logic systems, you can finally make your 50 meters squared chip in space.
- Factories, automation.
- AI-controlled turrets and probes.
- Awesome active community on the StarMade forums, and the StarMade registry.
- So much pros, I surely forgot something.

CONS:
- Glitchy, that's to be expected of an Alpha.
- Can crash on multiplayer... hope your ship was full-stoped before you did.
- Tough on low-performance CPUs
- Hard learning curve, you'd be best watching some tutorials on the web before throwing yourself in the game.
- Larger ships are incredible stronger than smaller ships due to buffs in shield systems and weapon systems depending on number of blocks, more on that later.

Now this game might be for €9.99, but it sure is worth twice as much, if I had one gift to do to a bored gamer, it would be this game.
It has been on developpement for about 4 years (More, already ?), but is still progressing at a sustained pace. The community can't wait to see further progress, and neither can I.
Ships will become overpowered exponentially with their mass, if one dreadnought is 50 megatons in mass, it will still be much stronger than 200 corvettes of 500 kilotons. This is due to the exponential increase in stats the more blocks you have connected in one array. This is sad because that can inhibate epic space fleet battles. Fighters will never be able to breach through larger ships due to the former having weak weapons compared to larger ships, and the latter having too much shield recharge rate for the former.
Schema and the developpement team plan on upgrading this though, to make smaller ships stronger and more of a threat, and larger ships more exposed to swarms of smaller ships.

I guess I'll take my leave, before this review scares other people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

first off I want to say do not take my word for it - just play the demo on a server with some people watch some youtube (I would recommend Bench" clear speaking right to the point) about some of the things you can come up with and hey the demo's free and its like 300MBs of download - why not try it?

so without further comments

so allot of people looking at this game compare it to minecraft or a simpler version of space engineers doing so however is a major lack of understanding - so to help clear things up

does it use blocks and a voxel based world like minecraft?
yes - the block based worlds are easier to build in and allow for more customization then solid pieces or snap to functions but the depth of creation from the varied blocks allow for many more then just cube designs

is it minecraft in space?
no - the customization from the game allows linking systems and custom designs that range from space stations to a colony on planets  to ships of any shape or size

is this space engineers simpler cousin?
no - while space engineers I agree has some better graphics and a few cool factors allot of it is premade blocks - want a anti missile or anti player turret just build one drop it - what a anti missile turret in starmade? decide on weapons dozens of choices of what to shoot down missiles with then how many barrels do you want - is a cloud of shrapnel more important? or is it a stream of minigun fire - its your choice the entire turret is custom made - like the turret save it for later - don't like it rebuild it

whats the big difference between space engineers and starmade? well the simple version is - starmades a game space engineers is a simulation - sure I know what your thinking whats the difference? a game doesn't let reality hold it down its meant to sit back and have fun on not determine if some angry newton lover is gonna blow you up for not useing the right real life science (seriously look it up they have a entire griefer based society that attacks people in space engineers for not using real science in construction of ships!) where as the community of starmade is far nicer and relaxed - people duel in pvp rather then stomp some noob - and the community you draw says allot about your game

so starmade sure it looks like other games - sure its a early access game - but what does that mean you get for 10 dollars?  (or 4 copies for 30 dollars meaning you and 3 friends can enjoy this game for the cost of 1 of the other 2 games)

in short just about unlimited space sandbox - want massive carriers or a simple fighter or anything in between - want to work on a multiplayer game as a trader or ship builder or even a pirate - do it - the people are friendly and mostly fun to work with - the new rail system was a game changer and people are not mad about it but over joyed about rebuilding

starmade is a gem in the rough at the moment and while they have a ways to go they already have more stuff to do then allot of 30+ dollar games out there that are finished so give it a try and you will not regret it if you love sandbox games"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starmade has been in development for a while, and it will be for a while longer. But updates are consistent, the core mechanics are solid, and the game already offers an ton of fun to those it caters to right now. But because it is still very much in development, a number of mechanics are still missing, meaning that for now it does cater to a more specific group. Namely the one that absolutely can't resist building creative things with a full suite of editing tools, blowing them up and strutting around in their creations in front of their fellow community members.

The comparison to Minecraft is easily draw of course, and one should rightfully compare the two. However, even in mimicing some elements, the game always implements them in its own unique way, making it a breath of fresh air for some veteran MC players like me. That said, the implementation is usually more complex and intricate than its counterpart, so be prepared for a learning curve, thankfully often rewarded with the awesome result of your contraptions.

For now, the worlds are pretty scarcely populated and static, meaning that if your desire is not to build and start exploring all sorts of wonderful places, you might be disappointed. A huge amount of content is planned, but it will take time, with the first of these updates hitting soon in the form of massively upgraded space stations.

Interfaces and tutorials are also quite barebones for the time being. Very useful and functional once you get a hang of them, but harder to learn and slapped together in places. If learning isn't your sort of thing, move on for now.

===================

In short, the game already features a great amount of mechanics that can provide you with a lot of fun if you like building, warping & blowing stuff up in your own creations, but for now, lacks content and might seem intimidating to players just starting out.

Good:
- Full suite of building tools
- Very optimised
- Very scalable
- Infinite universe
- Procedural damage & debris
- Innovative hexagonal planets

Bad:
- Improvised interface
- Lack of explorable content
- Steep learning curve
- Unbalanced economy

If you have any sort of creative or adventurous spark to you, definately try it and start creating or join a world without limits!

If not, maybe skip it and check back in another 6 months or so for the next batch of updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edited 28/8/15 after I put some more time into it:

I still stand by what I originally said, but there's a few things that I was missing:
- Pirate ships are defined by the server you're playing on, the default pirates are not particularly powerful but the ones on the server I was playing on are geared for aformentioned multimillion credit ships. The power disparity is being fixed in the future by assigning ships scores based on their components so waves of pirates spawn that are more tuned to your ship.

- Pirate stations spawn more frequently the further from the galactic centre you are, but with a radar jammer they're not particularly threatening.

- Combat balance has improved pretty significantly from when I originally made the review and I'm more happy with where it sits. Shipyards make repairing damage a lot less of a pain and shields are generally more powerful.

I still wouldn't recommend it, but it's on its path to being a decent game.


Original review:

I have mixed feelings on this game, but keep in mind it's still alpha and is subject to change.

First off, the good parts:
- The game is very atmospheric, abandoned stations really feel abandoned and ships are easy to design to give off particular vibes.

- The ship, building and station construction is pretty fun and there's more tools available than what you've got in minecraft, such as being able to specify an xyz area to fill in or placing a wireframe of a shape and being able to lock your construction to only let you place and remove blocks that are within that guide.

- The universe gives a very good sense of distance and getting pulled into a one-way wormhole and finding yourself 2000km from where you started is simultaniously spooky and awesome.

And the not so good parts:
- Combat is atrocious, creating viable ships is not obvious at all and too damn expensive, but of course the enemies are all equipped with them. The weakest pirates in the game will straight-up annihilate you unless you're flying a multimillion credit ship. The reason for this is twofold - I never saw a pirate alone, they always come in packs of 5 or more and defensive equipment is seriously underpowered. You can place hundreds upon hundreds of shield capacitors and the pirates will simply blow through your measily amount of shields in seconds and start doing hull damage. This is where they start to damage and destroy the actual blocks your ship is made up from, which gets very expensive very quickly. It's also demoralising to see a ship you worked on for 3 hours torn to shreds from a single, small-scale firefight.

- Enemies are too numerous. For how powerful they are you should only be seeing one or two of their home stations in a system, but you frequently see 6-8+ pirate stations, usually within firing range of the majority of the points of interest. This means evasion is simply not an option and even with a jump drive you're likely to land on top of a pirate station when travelling for more than a few hundred KM.

- Moneymaking is a boring grind, you equip a ship with salvage modules and spend 25 minutes firing beams at planets and asteroids hoping to find minerals to turn into materials to craft with. There's nothing to spice this up with, you just shoot beams at stuff until they're gone or you get bored. Most guides I read referred to looting abandoned stations for systems to sell or use, but as it turns out the devs thought that was too overpowered and so now every block you get on a station turns into a part which is 5:1 to a basic crafting block. I dismantled an entire station (with a build block to save my sanity) and only got a little over a hundred thousand credits after turning the debris into materials and then into engines. It just feels like an arbitrary restriction on an already lengthy grind for money.

- Less serious, but the default settings for the server config have some questionable values. By default the maximum speed is 75 m/sec, you'll want to crank that up to somewhere around 200-300. Space still feels big without having to spend 35 minutes flying through void to get somewhere.


As it stands, I can't recommend it. If it goes on sale for $3 or below and looks interesting to you, you probably won't regret it. Right now I'm regretting having paid the full $10 for it, but it might get better with time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have hundreds of hours in this game and yet I had to sit here for a few minutes to just decide what I was going to say about StarMade. In short, it is completely overwhelming. I spawned into my server and did the tutorial..... twice. I then realized how poorly made the tutorial is and proceeded to go find youtube videos on how to get started. This helped tremendously and I returned to the game ready to become a space exploring master.

I quickly built my first little ship and flew to a shop to buy some more parts with my starting credits. I had my first mining ship ready to go in a little over an hour and from that point the game has only gotten more awesome. I soon lost my first ship to a wave of rogue pirates and had to start over. I was upset but it taught me the simple truth that space is not a friendly utopia. My next ship was still a mining ship but I equipped weapons, light armor, and some shields to ensure my long worked for investment would not be lost again.

I now have some friends on the server with me and we have all started building capitol ships, cruisers, and stations. The game's building system is the most wonderful thing I have experienced in a voxel" style game. The ability to mirror on all 3 axes

what do you have to lose other than some time? It is definitely worth a look at least.

The controls are a bit clunky but that is because the range of motion and movement directions and ship menus are so plentiful they had to map nearly every key on the keyboard to a button. It takes some getting used to especially the getting around in 0G part.

The game is buggy and occasionally runs out of memory or has a java fatal exception. Its an EARLY ACCESS title and to expect perfection is just not realistic. It isn't even that common of an event honestly.

Even with the few negatives I've mentioned above this game is still unreal. The scope and size is just absurd. I looked at my first galaxy where I spawned in and realize it would take months to explore all of those stars. Then I found several neighboring galaxies and the realization dawned..... YOU ARE SO TINY AND INSIGNIFICANT. You are a speck of dirt in one solar system
votesFunny: in a galactic neighborhood with thousands of other solar systems
commentsCount: in a galactic cluster containing thousands of galaxies
column16:
in a universe containing thousands of galactic clusters..... It blew my mind to see the scale on the map. Sure it sounds "big" when its written out in text or as you see the stars from in the game. But opening that galactic map.... it is so overwhelming.



TL;DR

If you want an overwhelming space experience

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game for over a year now and it's done nothing but impress me. With the incredible amount of features already implemented, it's easy to forget that this is just an alpha. I've gone in an out of the tester staff and I can safely say this game is going in an excellent direction

Pros:
Fully-Functional Faction system
Several weapon combinations in game
Greater amount of detail for construction
Massive galaxies for explorational fun
Dev team that responds to criticism and input, and is personally involved with community

Cons:
Still an alpha product - a bit on the unstable side
Still needs a lot of optimization for servers
The community has a few bad apples that tend to be elitist as all hell, but this is relatively minor.


I'd recommend getting the demo since it's the same thing as the full version. If you really like it, buy it. But if early-access games and alpha games frustrate you, or maybe if you are really young and do not understand computers, go ahead and just get the demo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have 300+ hours off of steam
Edited on 1/12/16, Currently version 0.19538

The first thing you need to know is that for now you have to accept change, many things are changing currently. My opinions are based off of the current state.

PROS
Amazing building
Bi-weekly Updates
Varied Gameplay
Clever Building Mechanics, blocks have more than one use
Endless space; no loading screens or pauses
Multiple procedural stations designs
Customizable ship based weapons
Customizable ship engine properties
Commandable AI fleets
CONS
Can be difficult and time consuming
There are some balance problems, especially with combat
Server stability problems, but definately playable
Some glitches and exploits, but not many are gamebreaking
Not very moddable yet; but official mod API is planned
Ship movement is more like a mobile turret than a traditional sci-fi ship
StarMade vs Space Engineers
+Less laggy, slower computers can run it granted you have at least 4 gigs of ram
+SM is more akin to the X or freelancer series while SE is more like Garry's Mod*
+SM is free for the time being, the SM demo is the same as the full version
+Custom weapons and some custom tools
+SM ships can have moving parts that are reliable
+SM has player controled AI ships X3 style
-SE has far better superficial graphics*
-SE has far better animations regarless of style*
-SE feels clunkier and less responsive*
-SM planets and asteroids are very small compared to SE

*opinion based on the time I spent playing both games

This has been my first detailed review but I thought it was the least I could do for such an amazing game with such amazing devs.


Thanks for reading

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*DEMO VERSION = FULL GAME = FREE = YOU SOLD ME ON THIS GAME = HAPPY!*

First: A Review about the Price / Demo / Free Thing:

Other game companies vying for attention in the Early Access" Arena (huge competition there) should take note of what StarMade has done with their business model. They are offering the full version of the game as a "Demo" for Free. Yes Free. You can play it as much as you want now
date: during Alpha - and then decide to buy. I don't know of many other Early Access games that are doing this ... in fact many of them are asking 25 to 40 bucks or more just to play a buggy Alpha version of their game with no guarantee they're going to keep developing or finish the game. I don't really like those odds and I have thrown money into Early Access games that are now collecting dust in my Library because the devs just stopped working on it.\n\nStarMade is asking a very low price of 10 bucks right now ... that's less than you probably pay to go see a movie! DO IT. This price won't last. When the game grows in popularity and is more developed
recommended: that price will go up. This is smart marketing. Rather than asking a big up-front price for the Alpha and then slowly lowering that price via sales on Steam over time
hoursPlayed: these guys are smart. Ask NOTHING up front (Free Full Version / Demo) and a very small buy-in price. I'm impressed! Steam 'works' because players read reviews
voteText: players look at what's popular and selling fast in Early Access ... so asking a low up front price or even better
helpfulPercent:
letting us play it FREE will get this game a lot of attention and fast.

Now - The Game Review - Worth It?

YES - YES - YES.

This game is really solid for an early access game and has a lot more functionality and items than I was first expecting. I did not think it would have so many building parts and that exploring would be limited or simplistic in looks but WOW was I wrong.

This is Minecraft-In-Space!

Graphics - The textures
votesHelpful: colors and graphics are awesome - better than most minecraft texture mods.\n\nCrafting - Gathering resources is easy and fun -- no blocks dropping off into space or down holes ... just ZAP and it's in your inventory. Putting bits together is easy and though the GUI for the crafting screen is still pretty rudimentary
votesTotal: it's intuitive enough you can get it easily.\n\n*EDIT* (Dec 11th) - After playing this a lot more over the past 4 days
votesFunny: I have come to realize the crafting system in StarMade is actually very complex (deceptively simple looking at first) and takes some learning to get the hang of (videos by other players helped) - so don't be fooled by the simple Minecraft look - it's a lot more indepth. There are factories of varying levels and power supplies must be maintained
commentsCount: and parts for your ships must be manufactured and assembled in a more complex way than I first realized. Again
column16:
I am very surprised at how much complexity they've already put into such an early Alpha game. StarMade's been in the works for quite a few years and it shows with how polished the crafting system is. If you were afraid it would be too 'simple' then let me reassure you this crafting system will challenge even the most detail-oriented game crafters.

Tutorial - The Tutorial is very indepth and helpful (needs a little grammar / typo work - hey I'm for hire!) ;). I would advise doing the tutorial and then watching some player guides on youtube before you really start building your ship because it's somewhat tricky at first to get all the blocks in the right arrangement for a power efficient and secure ship while at the same time making it look good.

Ships - Building your ship is pretty simple once you get the hang of the control blocks and such. Again
column17:
do the tutorial! I've looked at some of the amazing creations others have made online (videos and screeshots) and am very impressed at the unique and endless possibilities for your ship creations. Imagine if some of the insane things you've seen built in Minecraft could lift off and fly through space!

Combat - I have done only a little of this so far being a newbie - but it seems solid and the options to upgrade and customize your ship's weapons is indepth and varied ... the crafting nuts who love space games (EVE Online?) will love this! There are shields and jammers and turrets and all the usual spacecraft type combat arsenals.

Exploration - Flying around is a joy and the controls are so simple even my 5 year old can do it and loves it. Radomly picking a direction and heading off into the great unknown of space for some far off sector of the galaxy is really fun and relaxing too. There's some good 'Explorer-zen' in this game.

Vast Universe - The Galaxy Map is pretty amazing too. I'm still trying to sort out navigating it but having a great time buzzing about the starter galaxy to get the hang of it. Scrolling out to see the sheer immense (infinite) size of the Universe was pretty mind boggling the first time!

Planets! - Last but certainly not least - The PLANETS.  O-M-G. I was absolutely stunned the first time I entered the atmosphere of my first planet and took a look at the amazing creation before me. The physics are well done and the geometric shape of the planet is fun and so very minecraft-esque! *Edit* Planets are "Dodecahedrons" technically! The planets actually slowly rotate and it's such a fun feeling to bounce around on them
column18: explore and gather minerals and such. Definitely my favorite part so far.\n\nSummary (TLDR): THIS IS MINECRAFT-IN-SPACE ... DO IT!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recently Picked this up.
I thought to myself that this would be a quaint little game.
As a matter of fact.. I didn't even install it for a week or two.. and barely took interest of it.
Then I decided to give it a shot.  Now I find myself losing sleep trying to construct large vessels that can destroy my enemies with as few shots as possible.   Now I have become power mad and began to exterminate pirates in my chosen sector just so I can rule over it (by myself.. but It's all good).  I been playing Minecraft for years and I have always wanted to be able to do this.  The game still feels a bit empty, but for now, that actually feels good to me.  Space feels lonely and cold and I enjoy warping through it with a giant battlecruiser I spent 7 days building.  Pirates can be derpy at times, it gives me a giggle when they suddenly stop moving and you can just tear them apart.
The tutorials in game are ok but not always sufficient, I really would of liked a more in-depth ship building tutorial.  I didn't fully understand how to make stronger weapons untill i decided to fight a pirate ship.
Nevertheless, It's a fantastic game to play and if you got it, play it!  If you don't got it, get it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

<[PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS GAME'S FULL VERSION IS FREE THROUGH THE DEMO UNTIL APLPHA IS OVER]>

Now that that small fact that most people miss ENTIRELY is over, let's get down to the review. My hours spent are fairly low in comparison to most of my other games, but I also spend quite a bit of time on the standalone version. Yes, you can download the standalone through the Starmade.org website. If you buy it here, you can link accounts and have full version there, aswell.

Actual features time.
+ The vistas you see in space are absolutley breathtaking.
+ Massive ships are made far easier to build using the Advanced Build Mode tools. Size sliders, anyone?
+ The community so far has been great. The skin system was fully released and fixed recently, so now you can make your astronaut look however you like.
+ Best weapons customisation I have seen in block cannons by far. You can slave systems to other systems to create combo weapons, such as seeker missiles or rapid fire cannons.
+ Great factions system, and while teh new chat took some getting used to, it's quite a bit better than the last one. (Messages scroll in the proper direction now)
+/- You can make amazingly huge ships, all it takes is time and dedication. However, these large ships can be laggy.
- Coded in Java, some users will experience issues.
- Still has some major bugs, but I havn't encountered any that have truley broken my game.

And that's about it on what I have to say. I would LOVE to see more texture packs from the community, and rotating blocks and joints would be amazing aswell. All in all, it's a good space battle and space ship building game.

[EDIT]: Just updated a few days ago, and the game is probably 50% better than it was before because of the new Rail system. Easy docking, the ability to move ships on rails... it's a beautiful thing. No more annoying docking boxes!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a man who plays many survival type games. I can say that I fell in love with this game. It's not so much survival, as it is more like Minecraft than it is Rust, but space pirates!

Mind you, I hate Minecraft. I put a lot of hours into it while I was away from home with no internet, but that game is boring, but it was the only limitless, unbeatablish, game I could play at the time. I also ran out of storylines on other console games.

I've gotten lost in the game and lost track of time. I'm a military guy. I go to sleep at 2200, wake up at 0530 and go to work. The past couple nights, I've stayed up till 0100 and woke up at 0530. The space exploration is fun. Finding planets and trying to build an epic ship. Pure Awesome. Accept the space pirates.. They like to blow up your ship and send you back into the void crying.

Totally worth the money. It's still in alpha (I'm pretty sure), and being so, starting the game for the first time took some googling, you have to dedicate ram to it yourself. To put it in fullscreen took googling, you have to go into the javascript and actually change part of the code *hint hint* You also have to go onto their site to register that you bought it through steam, which is simple. They are working on making it automatic, and seem like a great group of Devs.

I would give this game a 4/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are many block building games and clones, and from the screenshots and videos of Starmade you may feel that this is just another one. I caution you to not fall into this line of thinking and give Starmade a chance. As of this writing, the game is completely free to play and downloadable from the developers website during it's alpha period.

Is it Minecraft in space? No. It's a starship game with a block building motif.

Like many people cutting their teeth with block building games, I felt restricted. Even with mods and redstone advancement I felt my creations were static and dead. I felt any attempts to construct creations of grandeur were less not a matter of creativity but more overcoming the limitations that the game enforced. Resource management and collection was more of a hinderance than anything, and I spent more time micromanaging furnaces than playing the actual game.

With Starmade I felt free to explore and expand in any way I chose. Even in survival mode the pursuit of expansion seemed more rewarding and the progression of my ships was smooth. The game developers provided basic tools (admittedly with a bit of a learning curve) throughout to make sure that you are able to build and play the game fast. You spend less time flying around collecting materials as asteroids with resources are plentiful and respawn throughout the galaxies. Automation, factories, logic, and filtering sort your materials the way YOU choose. Building tools that mirror and place blocks in bulk, with in-game guides make it fast and easy to lay down your ship designs. Blueprints and shipyards make saving your designs and testing out new things a breeze.

Any aspect of the game of interest to you? Focus on it! You can go as big or small as you want. Build planet-sized mining rigs, or quick-rapid fire fighter craft... or make small stealth ships to just explore the universe. Best of all, the developers and community are in constant communications... sharing ideas and opinions, fixing bugs and adding enhancements to the game constantly. The list of upcoming features is fantastic and after watching it's development for years I have yet to see them cancel or reject a truly anticipated feature.

Starmade is one of the few games that I allowed myself to fall into because I felt there were no limits.

I played for three years, primarily before it was Greenlit. Starmade was the one game I could always come home to. It became my favorite game to play anytime I had free moment. Sadly, I am writing this review now only as I am parting ways with it.

Space, by it very nature, is empty. When you are lacking content you have to make your own fun, and it's hard playing multi-player games alone. It is true there are quite a few Starmade servers with players on 24/7, but the current state of the game does not encourage teaming up with those who may be untrustworthy. Factions are available though somewhat limited at the time of this writing, and there are no 'personal' access blocks. That being said, I can't get a single one of my gamer friends interested in playing Starmade.

I am not a game developer and will not attempt to act as if I know the solution, but when I demo Starmade to my friends from the ground up all they see is the void of space and not much else. In most survival games the start is a mad rush to get yourself equipped and protected as soon as possible. Your first dirt hut is an amazing achievement. In Starmade, you may as well never even leave the starting shop if you so choose. There is no call to action, no shove out the door, no impending doom, nothing making a new user wish to 'do' anything.

I believe in Schine (the developers of Starmade).  I have no doubt that with their efforts and the support of the existing fan base they will absolutely polish and shine Starmade into a diamond. I just don't know how long that it will take. With that in mind, it's time for me to dock my ship for now, shut down the reactors, mothball the factories, and close up shop.

So long, and thanks for all the fish.

Edit: Note - As of Jan 16th, 0.19549 personal blocks have been added. I will update my review further when I come back to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ah StarMade.

First off this is a fantastic game... don't get me wrong, so much potential, such a wonderful concept being brought to life! BUT and yes that is a big, big but.

There are some very serious issues with performance when it comes to loading planets.... like game dropping out issues, even when everything is turned to low it still does not help.

I honestly cannot get near most of them because they are too big and it causes a critical error. And no it isn’t my pc as I am running decent hardware.

Being Alpha I understand we are bug testing. So I am not angry as such, more disappointed at something that shouldn’t have even been an issue in the first place, the description says this game is built to run on older PC's and I am telling to right at this very moment this would not run on an older PC if my rig cannot handle it.

I recommend this game to those who are interested but I warn any who purchase that there will be that optimization issue that stops players from exploring some planets.

So devs:

1. Fix optimization issue
2. actually start us out on a planet and not right next to a space traging post where we can basically build a ship straight away.
3. fix descriptions as some of them don't even exist yet also there are spelling mistakes in a few of them.

Thats pretty much all I can think at this point in time, I will be sure to update you on gameplay and any other issues that in find :) Keep up the good work!


**EDIT**

Okay so for those who are also experiencing any issues with planets loading, I have found that if you get to the point where the planet just starts to load, press esc, alt+tab and do something else for 5 mintues while it loads.

Helped me get to a planet that actually crashed my game several times :)


**EDIT UPDATE**

So after another hour or 2 I have managed to get a fair amount of materials, storage and am starting to build a large enough ship to hopefully raid a pirate station (hopefully), I have a homebase with its own spawn point and am slowly but surly working towards my own station!

Gameplay and performance seem to get better as you get further through the game, maybe that's just y patience improving.... I don't know haha.

Overall this game really has me wanting to play more and more with every second I play it. SO with that being said I give it a 10/10 rating (y)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game and unlike some of the nay sayers, I've put in the time to be able to give an educated review. If I were to give you description of what the multiplayer side of this game is, I would have to say it's shapping up to be a cross between Mincraft and EVE. So far the game is Minecraft in space with a touch of EVE, but with the direction they are going it will end up like I stated. As for single player, it's completly Minecraft in space.

The things you can build in this game are only limited by how far you're willing to go! You can build simple stuff or go bat sh*t crazy and build a fully 1:1 working space station. If you want the ship to rise from the ground out of a hidden hanger, you can build it. Like I said, the game wont limit you as to what you can build.

I highly recomend this game! If you like Mincraft and space games Starmade is all that and more and keep in mind this is still in alpha, so much more is comming!
