reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would like to start right off by saying I highly recommend this game.

The main reason I recommend this game is the devs. The devs seem to be interested with what the community wants and they keep you up to date on what they are working on. Devs like this are what make Early Access games worth it.

Another reason is the community. I yet to find one person that is a complete jerk. Also, people seem to make some amazing creations. I find it so entertaining when you finish building a ship that you think is so brilliant and you decide to join a server to show it off to find out someone has made a ship 50x stronger. It's just great to see all of the different ships.

These two reasons are what make me love this game better than any game in my Library. But, there are of course problems with it.

The biggest problem is the amount of players in servers. A game like this with trillions of galaxies should definately have at least 100 players a server. The problem is you're lucky to see 10 players at a time on a server. This could of course easily be fixed by people getting the game, which I really hope happens.

The idea of this game getting popular makes me overjoyed. I would love to see big faction wars between 2 major factions and a bunch of miniature allied factions assisting them. Also, a few huge mother ships sending out a bunch of fighter jets, which can actually happen. This stuff is implemented into the game, the problem is there is no people to join those factions.

I would love to see this game get players. It has outstanding potential as long as these devs are able to keep working on it. But, that won't happen if the game gets thrown aside and in my eyes, that would be a tragedy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy ♥♥♥♥.


At first it's a little confusing to understand and a bit challenging to get started. Who doesn't like a good challenge though? But after using a few of the community guides and experimenting with things it ends up being an amazing game. This is basically a space sim. You build a small ship. Then build a bigger ship. then maybe build a space station for all your ships. Definitley better with friends, but is fun in singleplayer as well.

Of course this is still in alpha and it does have tons of bugs and crashes sometimes. I'm looking forward to watching this game grow and seeing the final project.

If you get fustrated easily with bugs and things like that don't buy this game. Yet. Wait until it's finished or something. Still a great game so far. There's already so much ♥♥♥♥ to do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great game.
It's lots of fun.

Here is a story about my adventure in it.

I gathered resources and proccessed them, then I made a jump drive, which takes time to charge.
after it charged, I decided to jump to a nearby undiscovered station.
As soon as I finished warping, I saw a turret turning towards me and knew it was time to leave.
I flew away from the station as fast as I could, and started repairs.
Then I noticed red arrows on my GUI. I knew instantly it was time to run.
As soon as I entered my ship I saw shots flying towards me. I started to charge the jump drive.
as it was charging I turned around and fired at my pursuers. I hit them about twice before we got too far to really hit accurately. My jump drive fully charged and I jumped to a planet nearby.

I would rate this game 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers are awesome. They don't even seem to care about the money, I have noticed they care about their game, and community.

A comparison to space engineers, as it is similar in many ways:

Pros of this game:
- This game has less physics and graphics to be rendered, therefore it is better for people who have a low-end computer. I get around 500 fps on this game, right in a new world, space engineers only around 50-60
- As the point above, it also goes well for being able to handle many players and big ships on a server without issue.

Pros of Space engineers compared to this game
- SE has more modding support, with many mods that add new decoration and weapons.
- Better physics, with voxel damage. even though this is a big factor in lag.

Both games
- Both have practically infinite worlds, at least ones we'll never need any bigger of.
- Both can be really good for custom ship space battles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is for space enthousiasts who can imagine building stations and ships, then go out to hunt pirates and PvP. There's plenty of logic/weapons to make things move/shoot and the dev is constantly adding updates. It's one of those EAs, yes they exist.

Think big. Plenty of resources in no time will get you going with large projects which is why you should go multiplayer to work together. The construction helper will certainly speed things up. The universe is endless, there's just too much to do in this game. I regularly need to force myself away from the computer because my brain doesn't want to stop pouring out new ideas at 4AM.

So if you are like me and just want to play one game where you unleash all your creativity and build up long-term then this is for you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is the game i have been searching for for nearly my entire life. I like a few things in specific: Strategy, Sandbox, sci-fi, Factions, and community. I tried Eve Online, but the subscription ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off. I tried Minecraft, but it was too basic. I tried Starbound, but it's only 2d and doesn't have depth. THIS fits all the rules. You start as a character with essential supplies and you just need to survive. Single Player can be boring, but the multiplayer servers make this game live up to its potential. Make alliances, kill space pirates, build ships, watch them get wrecked, build better ships, wreck the ships that wrecked yours, and explore in an almost (if not) infinite universe. And about worrying about people taking your precious supplies or looting your corpse? Don't worry, When you die you keep your inventory, and in a faction you can choose one planet/space station where NOBODY can steal your stuff. Join this ever-expanding community today and learn the arts of the explorer, the empire builder, the captain, and the Warrior. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who likes the genres i previously stated.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, after playing this for 116 hours I thought I'd share my view of this game. So first, yes I know this is an early access title, but the tutorial kinda' sucks to me. I was still clueless on what to do afterwards, but perhaps maybe I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, idk. The game feels a bit empty with nothing to do, but I wasn't expecting much considering it's an early access title. The reason I've been playing so long was simply out of sheer excitement to keep building onto my ship, and even try to make a little mech or something haha (it's extremely time consuming). It's strangely addicting.

It's a sandbox space sim where you start off with nothing but a few things in your inventory. You have a ship core, you hit the X key to create a new ship, name it, and then you build onto it with parts, etc. To make stuff you need to mine of course, so you go out in space and find asteroids or planets and mine them. After you mine and get resources, you need to make factories in order to make stuff with what you mined. Pretty simple, like most crafting games. You can build ships, bases, create factions, you can claim solar systems and make them your faction territory, you can go and fight pirates and destroy their bases. But thats really all there is to it (or at least from what I've seen). With that being said, I think this game was aimed more at multiplayer.

It's not a bad game, just wish it didn't take me 100 years to figure out what to do when I first started playing. And also, the pirate stations seem to be there to troll you, as you cannot mine them after you take them out, instead you have to pay an exorbitant amount of money to repair them (15mil), which is really silly to me and kinda defeats the purpose. Idk why the devs did that. Without the help of guides and YouTube videos, i'd be lost and wouldn't have played as long as I did. I do recommend this though, I can't sit here and act like it wasn't fun. Just understand that it's early access, it has bugs, and still needs a lot of work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game! I've played it for the past year or so and have watched it grow up so quickly. The developers really put a lot of effort into this game. One thing I wanted to clarify. This is NOT minecraft PLUS space. This is minecraft IN space. Don't expect the typical tools you would find in minecraft. The whole idea for this game is to build spaceships and live in space. Currently living on the ground is quite rudamentary. I'm pretty sure that there are plans to improve the ground aspect, but at the time of this review these features are quite non existent.

Yes there are warp gates
Yes there are space stations
Yes there are warp drives
Yes you can have multiple people command one ship

This game is really fanstastic. I'm amazed at the talent of the developers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game when it was for around 3 dollars. Now its on the Steam, damn a lot of progress has been made and I'm glad I supported this game for so long.

If you look for a singleplayer experience with a rich story you will be dissapointed becouse there is no story, you need to shape the story by yourself ( aka roleplaying ).
Especially with a friends its a lot of fun but real funs begins on the servers ,here is when this game shines *for now*. You can attend in the amazing community events and space battles.

I'm not sure what else to write about this game. Yeah its a early acess game but you can feel safe becouse Schema (developer ) is a really cool guy. You won't get your money *stolen*.

For me best part of this game is a ship building , you can build a small jet or colossal capital ship or a ship carrier.
You can build space stations too and even colonize planets for yourself or your faction or if you like you can planet-crack them for a valuable resources if harvesting asteroids is not enough for you.

If you preffer PvP its not a problem, this game has a really extended weapon system. Combat system might be a little bit unbalaced but hey its still beta testing.

Thats all, worth a buy if you like to socialize or roleplay with the people. Or like me you like to build stuff.

Engange~

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers have big, big plans for this game.  They're an ambitious bunch and they work hard to put out a consistent stream of updates WITHOUT leaving the game riddled with bugs and breaking save files.

Update:
I've seen a lot of reviews complaining about lack of content.

First, think of Starmade more of a Minecraft in space at this current stage in development.  The universe IS empty.  And at this very moment, the Dev's are holding a ship building contest to add 2 more factions and a larger variety of ships to the universe.  Until you build it or join a server, your world will be just as empty as Minecraft's world.  But what you CAN build...is freaking gorgeous.

Second, updates.  Like I said, when they do update, they do it right.  Without game breaking bugs, without ruining save files.  Do I want to see more updates?  Of course I do!  But everything I have seen since I've purchased the game, I am happy and excited for.  Their last update, FLEETS, made me drool on my keyboard.  I have seen what's in the Dev's heads in their roadmaps, and slowly but surely they'll deliver.

Starmade is a fine Early Access title.  Want to see a bad one?  Here:
http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198154661444/recommended/285920/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally this amazing game has made it to Steam!

This game is amazing to play with some friends and not only create fleets of handbuilt ships (that you create block by block, system by system) but planetary headquaters, massive space stations, and deep space mining platforms.
There are plenty of ways to play this game, with the amount of freedom given to the players. Massive PvP battles, solo merchant trade route stuff, pirate hunter, miner, ship builder, etc. Hell, even just exploring the massive galaxy is fun. It's full of planets, asteroids, and other neat things like pirate bases and space stations.

I've been playing Starmade for a very long time and the developer never ceases to amaze me. He practically single handedly has created the best space sandbox to date and continually improves it more and more. I've never seen any game receive as much love as this one.

As long as you're not turned off by the voxel based engine there is just so much to love here. Even it's weakest elements are usually better fleshed out than comparable games. Just give it a try and if you like it support this awesome developers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a Dell XPS Laptop which has two video processors, one is the onboard Intel video that it uses when it is on battery power (low power) and the other is an nVidia GT540M (for full AC adapter power).

I have configured StarMade (and Java) to run on the nVidia card (just like I do with all my other games including Minecraft) using the nVidia Control Panel. The nVidia card has the latest drivers. I also have the latest version of Java 8.25 64 bit. OS is Windows 7. To be perfectly honest I never use the Intel onboard video unless I am using MS Office or something simple like that because it is just plain aweful with 3d games. Nonetheless, my onboard Intel video has the latest driver available from Dell for my specific laptop.

The game does not cooperate with my nVidia control panel, and so the only way I could get it to run was to make my nVidia card as primary video on my laptop always, thus by-passing the nVidia Optimus controls.

Changing review to Tentatively Recommend""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS Introductory Review:

StarMade is a voxel-based sandbox that gives you the infinite expanses of outer space to build, craft, and venture. Yes, there’s no way around it, this is essentially Minecraft in space.

It’s not long been released on Steam Early Access where you can purchase it for $9.99 on Windows, Mac, and Linux. But it has been playable in its early stages before Early Access for quite a while. It’s actually been in the making since 2010.

In StarMade, you can build your own spaceship block-by-block, customizing it with weapons fit to take on space pirates – you’ll need them. Once satisfied, you can then get into your spaceship in order to explore distant stars and galaxies.

You’ll come across more than pirates too, as there are abandoned space stations to pick from, and the treasures you find inside can be traded to make a fortune. Or, you can use the materials to make your own space station, or a factory, all in order to make huge quantities of sellable items for a profit.

In multiplayer you’ll be able to find other factions, which you can join or fight against, and I’m sure you’ll be glad to hear that StarMade has dedicated servers.

The idea behind StarMade is to provide you an infinite space to make your own way within. As in Minecraft, you do as you please, exploring the various possibilities of the game’s intricate sandbox design.

Abstract:

??/?? (Awaiting Full-Release)

Recommended for it's current state at $9.99, there is enough content to keep you occupied for hours. I played this game before I purchased it on Steam, so I knew what I was getting into.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a mix of Minecraft and Eve Online.  You build your own ships, space stations and planetary facilities.  You even get to build custom turrets and thanks to the linking system your weapons are custom designs too.  The master builders and community in general have released tons of highly detailed massive ships and space stations for you to use if you want to as well.  You can destroy planets and go to war with other player factions in multiplayer for people that enjoy PvPing.  If you prefer to explore you'll never run out of new places to go with over 9 quadrillion galaxies.  I've only fully explored 3 galaxies in a server before.  Each galaxy is just massive and full of pirates, planets, asteroids, trade stations, shop stations, and derelict stations/ships (as of now, soon to be even more to explore) so it's easy to get sidetracked.

The Devs for this game are very involved with the community.  If you think you have a good idea for the game you can submit it on their forums and they'll actually take a look at it and implement it if the community supports/likes the idea.  They also have a road map (google Starmade Roadmap Trello) so you'll have an idea of what to expect for major updates.  They do graphical updates as well and quite frequently update textures into high res textures.

I've been playing this game since the rail update.  I just recently started logging hours through steam though.

Don't be discouraged by any of the negative reviews as most of them are people with technical problems that never sought out Starmade's support team.  The singleplayer version of this game is free to download so try before you buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing sandbox game that lets you build the spaceship of your dreams. You can play the game as a astronaut in a nearly endless universe, salvage asteroids, ships, stations and planets and use the resources you get to make blocks with factories. Then you can either use these blocks to build ships or sell them to others for credits.  Or play in a creative mode where you use admin commands to get the blocks needed and make the most amazing ships.


Its worth getting because:

1. With a decent pc you can have lots of ships in a sector.

2. With enough skill you can make any ship you want. (check out other people's work and you will know what I mean)

3. There are lots of modules that you can put on your ship.

4. The game has almost everything you need for a space sandbox. (FTL!!!)

5. A nearly infinite universe, so there is always room to build more and expand your faction territory!


For a space sandbox game I give this game a 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[written after the thrusters update]
Firstly, before a discription, many people may have seen outdated reviews and I would like to clear up some things. They have creative mode. They have slabs like in minecraft. They have teleporters (still being worked on but are useable). Missiles aren't the most powerful weapon in the game.

This is one of my favorite games, but I know some people who don't like it very much. It is still in early access, so if you are looking for a polished, complete game, go away.

Now for a discription. You can do almost anything you can think of in this game. It comes with lots of colors (pink and teal hull now!), weapons and details. And pirates to blow up. The developers have large plans and continue to make it better every two weeks! If you want a space sandbox where you can build the spaceship of your dreams, this is the game for you. If you are looking for a survival based game, I wouldn't buy it right away, because it is more of a sandbox than a survival. It does however have really good physics. Explosions are realistic and obviously thrusters were re-done. The weapons are also getting more balanced so missiles aren't OP and you can 1-shot anything. Even if they weren't they redid ship health so its more of breaking essential parts than blasting at a core. Basically this game has loads of content, but not around all areas like crew.

Please don't compare this to space engineers This isn't really aimed to compete with them. This is more of a building - fighting fantasy game than... survival? I have only seen the trailers for space engineers but it looks more realistic than fantasy-ic. It still looks good though, I'm not saying its bad. This game is just more of a build anything game. So FROM WHAT I HAVE SEEN: space engineers = survival, so get that if you want to survive in space, and starmade (from what I have played) = build a functional dream ship and blast pirates, so get this if you want to... do what I just sayed.

SHORT(ISH) DESCRIPTION
Now if you are a guy looking for a short description if the game (like me), here is what I can come up with: A block-based building game where you can build the ship of your dreams that actually functions and blast pirates with it. If you are wondering about multiplayer: Team up with friends and fight to the death in a battle of empires... or if your just playing with friends troll around with pirates and have fun laughing at the sad trading guild ships... until they use start using your blueprints...

So that is really all I have to say. Don't underestimate what this game is aimed to be. Just look at the dev. plans somewhere. Or just the game itself. It isn't as bad as really old reviews say. I hope you think this is good if you buy it. Schine is really serious about its quality and brings constant updates (if 2 every  weeks is constant for you).

10/10 would explode pirate stations again. Oh wait i can... (hears deafening explosion and laughing)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all I would like to say...
WOW!

Ok this is a space Minecraft style sandbox game but for a fresh release on early access on Steam...
it's amazing !

THE LAYOUT:

After a quick tutorial (some aspects of the game are still missing...), you start near a cotton bud" looking space station.

You are an astronaut and with few credits and items you are left in a huge universe.
First you have few blocks to build a basic spaceship. If you are smart enough
date: you will be able to go anywhere and enjoy the huge number of planets
recommended:
asteroids and stations you can find (nearly infinite).

THE GAMEPLAY:

Ship and stations designs are easy. By pressing Space after entering a Ship core
hoursPlayed:
you can launch building mode.
The Ship core it some kind of box where the player can enter and control the ship.
It's a strange way to use vehicles but the designer is enough well made to compensate this strange design.

Like in Minecraft you use blocks
voteText: you place them with left click and delete with right click (you have tons of other contols by pressing left ctrl).\nFor every ships
helpfulPercent: you have to plan it's energy usage and mass.\nThe bigger the more expensive it will be for you: like the cloak wich needs more energy depending of the size  of the ship. The interresting aspect of this mode is the way you use weapons and tools.\nEvery items needs a computer to be used. You put an appropriate computer and the weapon or tool block related
votesHelpful: and you conect them. The funny thing is that you can mix weapons and some upgrade blocks to change their effects
votesTotal: like EMP or Shield Drain
votesFunny:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minecraft

Yes, you might think that looking at the very familiar block style voxel building, but DONT.  You might think that again the first time you land on a planet and see trees and grass and hills, but DONT.

THIS IS NOT MINECRAFT

This is StarMade, you are in space, you mine your resources with a laser, and you build your own ships.  You will not find another space game with this much freedom and this much beauty.  You might think it's a little complex at first, but the concepts are simple, and you will pick them up easily with a little research.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, I'll be straightforward: I almost gave this game up within 5 minutes. My first impression was horrible. But I'm glad I persevered.

As for the long text review: there's a summary in the end.

Also if you don't like text and prefer a video over text, have a glance at how powerful the game is and just how much cool stuff and creativity you can have with it in this example.

Intro
I got it as part of a bundle some time ago and decided to give it a try. The launcher was not the best experience. When I finally got in-game, the tutorial was broken. As if this was not annoying enough, without a tutorial I was *completely* lost and had no idea what to do. Oh, and the sound was bugged. It took me quite a while to find how to fix it. Then the performance was horrible and again it took me a while to find how to fix it (increase allocated memory, get Java 64x). So I ditched Starmade and was glad I did.

By the way: The tutorial was quickly fixed, and a new launcher is underway. This sums up quite nicely one of the positives of this game: The devs. They're active, they're quick, they're good. But most of all, they are just part of the community. I started watching a few tutorial videos and whatnot on youtube and only after I had watched quite a few I realized at least two of the youtubers were actually devs. They're so helpful and chill it's unbelievable.

After watching online some of the stuff people were doing with the game and how so many love it I decided to give it another go -- now with the knowledge of where to find solutions to the problems I'd certainly encounter: Youtube, and to some extent the forums. Oh and I'm so glad I didn't give up.

Main
Then onto something that might be a pro or a con, depending what you're looking for: This game is whatever you make of it. So if you're looking to hop into space and find everything done and ready... keep looking. Here you start with pretty much nothing, in the middle of the vast space and next to a shop. Go from there, good luck. It's up to you what you want to build or do. Where you want to go. With whom you want to ally and play. And so on.

The big pro is that the limit is just your creativity. The possibilities are vast. If you like being creative, inventive, ingenious, and if you like to build not only your own game but a whole universe (ok, a whole stronghold" in universe) -- then this is for you.

The cons stay pretty much on the realm of the interface. The interface can be pretty powerful but many many aspects are really non-intuitive. Also the launcher is really barebones (thankfully a new one coming). The tutorial is also quite lackluster
date: so there's no other way: To learn tricks and all the power the interface has you have to dedicate some time to watch tutorials and whatnot. Thankfully there's plenty of good ones so no excuses there.\n\nBugs exist
recommended: as well as some balance issues and whatnot. But it's a game in alpha so they are quite ok. And I know nowadays it's a bit old to put a half-arsed game out there and call it alpha as an excuse to have produced a crap game. But this is not the case with these guys: They're hard at work
hoursPlayed: and updates and content are being churned out quickly. All that with lots of transparency and community input. Just a couple of days ago I was in a Q&A session with them (and I'm a nobody!) that lasted some 3 hours
voteText:
in which the replied to a ton of questions and played/had fun with the community. Thumbs up!

So to sum it up
Pros:
Vast
helpfulPercent: both in terms of "map size" (pretty much infinite) and in terms of possibility;\nBe creative
votesHelpful: build your own world
votesTotal: your own ships
votesFunny: and do it your own way;\nVery active
commentsCount: supportive
column16: friendly and helpful devs;\nAn active community with lots of tutorials
column17: general help
column18: and content to download (like ships
column19: stations
column20: skins
column22: yeah they're to be expected
column23: but they're there;\nAmong them I'm mostly bothered by the sound. Or lack thereof. It often bugs out and goes nearly silent;\nThe mp can be a bit spread thin
column24: with many servers having just but a few people logged in each;\nBalance can be a problem
column25: and more veteran players have a huge upper hand upon novices;\nYou can bypass the last one by playing single player for a while
column26:
or by playing on a strictly PvE server. But doesn't that spoil the whole point of the game? Maybe. It's your choice.
There's not all that much "environment" as of yet (although devs say much will be added). So at this point the universe feels a bit empty and plain until people (and mostly you) start to actually build stuff.
Conclusion
It's hard to give a note. On the one hand if you're expecting a somewhat "polished"
column28: you'll be greatly disappointed. On the other hand
column29: if you're into being creative and being responsive for the creation of your own experience
column30: then this can easily be an 8/10 -- with the potential to go at least up to a 9 once a few things like the sounds are sorted.\n\nI highly recommend it
column31: if it's the kind of experience you're looking for and you are prepared to what's involved in grabbing it yourself.\n\nps: And as time passes the game only gets better with frequent updates. The ideas the devs still have "in the oven" make me very excited for the future of this title."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game can be hard to get used to, once you get past the clunky controls, and unorthodox UI design you'll realize this is a game with amazing potential and amazing features. The developers have done something that hasn't been done for a long time - actually let players try the game without hassles or schemes. Becuase of this, i was able to discover that StarMade is what i've been looking for in a space game for a long long time. I highly reccomended that anyone who loves Space Engineers or Minecraft give this a try, becuase this really is a great game. It's not the same, but it has some similiarities. In this game, problems are solved with blocks, and i think thats something to appreciate.

This game is best played in a Multipalyer setting, however i DO reccomended that you play single player for your first 20 hours to make sure youre ready for a PvP setting. There are lots of little things that i had to discover the hard way, and while it was fun, some might not be as interested in tough love as i am.

I really hope this game takes off. I haven't felt so much love for a game since i first tried minecraft.

EDIT: Rail systems are a blast. I've already made an auto ship dispenser for my ship's hanger. I love this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really good, even at its early alpha stage. For the features that are in they are fairly well implemented as well as a whole, there are more features in so far then some games have at full release. Gameplay and look is similar to how games like Minecraft and similar 3d open world sandbox games where you make your own story. It is obviously in space, even though you can go onto planets.

The game at this moment is capable to being modded, with its Block Editor(which allows you to make/modify new or existing blocks). The server config which is also the configs for single player is fairly customizable, with the ability to toggle/change settings that are normally reserved for mods in other games.

Ships are dynamic in that they are all different based on what you built them with and what types of moduals you placed in them. Also the fact that you can mix and match compatible moduals together to create a new type of weapon or utility tool. The most common example is that by default a salvage(aka mining) modual will just do a burst beam, but if you connect the salvage computer to a cannon computer with just the right ratio of moduals you can get a constant steady beam for the salvage modual and mine/eat things to your heart's content.

Building is fairly straight forward for its most used functions, as well as for those who want more tools, there are more precise tools and options. Gameplay is very much like other games of it's genres. As a side effect though, with this game's many options and complexity, there will obviously be a learning curve. Where the player will need to learn how to setup the blocks and moduals, as some have their own placement rules. Thankfully there are many tutorials and Lets Play videos out there so learning will not be too difficult.

In all I recommend this game to anyone who likes; space games + open world sandbox games + lots of options, for its $9.99 USD price at this moment. As well as the developers currently have the full game for free as long as it's in early access. I bought it though, because it's pure awesome in my opinion, and I'll gladly pay the $10 for the game as well as the fact that buying the game helps to continue it's developement.

Early Access Review

Do you want your creations to move? Do you want to build massive ships that work? Do you want to go crazy with logic and make a space station that loads and unloads cargo? Are you someone who doesn't need their hand held? Then this game is for you.


-Pros

FULL GAME IS FREE IN DEMO (Until it leaves development)

Devs update the game often

Devs have a roadmap

Devs are active on forums

You're only limited by your own imagination

Endless space

-Cons

Feels like there is no sound. (Feels like =/= there isn't)

Not enough AI interaction to keep someone busy in
single player if they aren't focused on building alone.

Will eat RAM (Seriously, don't be messing around with only 2g of RAM)



Conclusion: If you don't need your hand held and you can entertain yourself, buy the game. If you're not sure, get the demo. The demo is the full game. There is no reason to not at least try the game if it's your kind of thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only just scratched the surface to this game and from the initial concept I can see what it's trying to achieve. It's essentially minecraft in space with a good dose of space sim play like that in Elite and Eve online.

It does have however it's caveats;
The tutorials are clunky to the extent it's easy to miss key components, and the ship management needs to be drastically simplified. Such as connecting weapons to computers should for the novice user, be automatic and not manually mapped and so forth.

It has a ton of bugs, yes I know it's early access I get that. But I understand this games been around for awhile prior to being released here on Steam. So you would think something as simple as sound would be a priority. I've ran this on two systems with it either silent or randomly loud repetitive fx's.

If you build a ship, fly off then start the tutorial, forget about your ship. On return spawn you are back at the beginning with your ship lost in space. And without a core to build another ship your essentially screwed and have to wipe the universe and start again.
Hopefully the above bugs get sorted out in further builds.

You would think with the bugs and clunky ship building I wouldn't recommend this game. For early adopters who want to see this game develop, bugs and all, I would say go for it. And I'm keen to see where this goes.
For those who expect the concept being sold here is what you'll get, taking into consideration that yes this is an early access game, then I ask you save your coin and come back later.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen I first seen this game I thought ahh Minecraft in space with some EVE undertones and that is what it is. I totally give the Devs a salute for their love for this game. They are a small team so at times when personal stuff comes up you do notice a slow down but the care and love is there, If you are like me and tired of developers that just want your money and you wonder if one day the game will just be dead then have no worries about the Schine team. As far as gameplay goes It's kind of boring playing by yourself but so is Minecraft. The build tools are amazing and make up for that plenty as you can see from my hours played. You have 5 basic shapes of blocks which I think does make for a more Minecraft feel even though they could do more variety with the second gen voxel system the game uses. I'd like to see more but i can respect if it is to keep the blocky feel of the game. They do alot on making multiplayer very viable and there has been a lot of focus there.  It's private servers like Minecraft but there are public websites and people who run them that let anyone in like minecraft if you want a bigger server to play on. Google it and you will get a good list. So I say give this game a try if you want Minecraft in space and to take what you build into battle. The Schine team has accomplished a lot since I bought this as far as adding quailty into the game and it's gameplay. Plus they are always working on something so you can expect more from these guys.  This game is worth the price and you will not regret it in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great concept for a game but when it comes down to it but it seems as though the developement is snail pace. From what i understand this game has been out for years and hasnt really progressed. The community has been waiting over a month since the last update for bug fixes that are killing gameplay.

While indeed the game is fun it is not particularly stable. Servers are a whole other story entirely. Server support seems minimal or just poorly done, either or.

This game is only fun with other people, there is no real single benefit apart from unlimited blocks, but even then that kind of kills the point in my opinion. I would stay away from Single player and join a multiplayer server but that obviously brings you to encounter the above.

What devs dont seem to realise nowadays is people would prefer a stable game over faster released additional content. People are ditching this game for purely this reason. Its like trying to put together a new desk while standing on your head..overall you're creating more problems for yourself in the long run.

When it comes down to it I paid the money for this game so i'm going to stick with and hope for the best. I do enjoy the game and have played a lot of hours but everything above causes so much frustration.

I do of course understand this game is still in Alpha but if given the choice im not sure I would purchase this again.

Summary ~ Great concept, shoddy execution.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update: With all of the new bug fixes and updates, I'll be playing the game soon, and then revising this review as needed.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Currently the ONLY reason to buy this is to support the developer, which I have no problem doing, but based on the history of early access games on Steam - most buy an EA game, and then are upset at the lack of features, even though the EA concept is clear.  So, if you are one of those people - pass on this for now.

For others, I'll state that while you can build some ships and travel through space, flying through space is very slow and as others have noted, there isn't really much to do - you can mine stuff and you can salvage stuff - oh, and you can sell stuff to the shop in order to buy stuff.  There's stuff, stuff and pirate stations...

Despite the lack of other stuff, the game shows potential.  I really like the build aspect for the spaceships as it allows for lots of customization, but flying the ship isn't that great because of the overall control scheme - switching between flying and building shouldn't be so easy that you do it by accident and end up exiting and losing the ship in deep space.

I didn't play this game before it came to Steam, so don't know how the planets were before, but the current design is...interesting.  They have a good size to them and I actually like the multi-faceted appearance, but travelling from one face of the planet to another is kind of weird (in both a good and bad way).  One thing I don't like so far is that there doesn't appear to be liquids - lava is simply a glowing non-flowing block - dig one out from under another and the hole remains with the other lava block just floating" over it.

Another thing I feel needs to be improved - space stations.  I know they pushed an update that changed the mix of abandoned versus pirate stations
date: but considering how long it takes to fly anywhere
recommended: it is still a pain to travel a long distance only to see you're being shot at by a pirate station or that the station is degraded
hoursPlayed: thus only good for scrap - and you'll need more than scrap if you want to upgrade your engines in order to fly faster.\n\nTo summarize - unless you simply wish to support the dev and/or really like space games/sims
voteText: I'd wait until more of the features are added to the game.  At that time I'll revisit this review and hopefully change that "no" to a "yes!""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

StarMade is basically minecraft in space.

Why I have 200 hours into this game
It is all about building if you want it to be
It is all about killing pirates if you want it to be
It has (like Minecraft) Incredible replay value.
There is no limit (Other than your computer) to the sizes of your ships.
The demo is currently the full game

Why I don't play it too much anymore
You have to be extremely patient when building bigger ships.
There isn't too many good servers anymore.

Overall I give a 7.5/10

EDIT: This game is EXTREMELY RAM intensive, I personally use 16gb out of the 24gb I have.
And if you are in space battles with your friends or other players it can be extremely processor intensive.

Also, Do NOT get this for the survival mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game back when it was $3 on the website (maybe 1.5 years ago?) And I was in-love with it, you could build anything you wanted in space. Be an asteroid miner, be a fighter, cruiser, dreadnaught, anything. And with multiplayer, the RP scene is pretty big. I recommend this game for anyone who likes games like space engineers (It's like that but not as complicated or taxing on your pc), or people who enjoy minecraft, and anyone who likes space.

The planets: When I bought the game they used to be flat round discs, now they're multi-sided (3d-octogonal?) You can land on them, get out of your ship, and explore them.

The pirates: There are npc pirates in this game. They're fairly difficult at first, but once you get a semi-decent ship they're easy. You can set them to use your own ship designs if they become waay too easy.

Stations: There are two types of stations in the game. Pirate stations, and Abandoned stations. The pirate stations have turrets and spawn pirates, these have loot that can earn you a LOT of money (Very dangerous with custom ships). Abandoned stations, they're just abandoned, they used to be completely empty, but now they spawn npc drones that attack you (Like a defense system). Mine the plexglass on the top to make lots of money too.

Thank you for taking the time to read this, and hopefully I helped you with purchasing this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update: I stand by everything I said.

This is the best game I have ever played. Its more like EvE then minecraft. Better crafting the Minecraft. I can not stress how cheap this is for $10 bucks. Still in alpha and is already better then EvE Online. Let me say that again........ ITS BETTER THEN EvE Online! Let that sink in.

The crafting system allows you to create anything you can imagine and its very well balanced. For instance you can make any ship currently in EvE, and if you don't like there design you can tweak it to your hearts content. The primary gameplay focuses on taking and hoding sectors of space. Your faction claims them and then gains faction points based on how much they currently control. You can make turrets, drones, titans, all with AI control so you can gurad your systems while offline.

You can create space stations, and colonize planets. You can board and hijack ships and stations. The game is simple to understand and learn, but would take a lifetime to master every intricicy. Bigger is not better in all cases. A small covert ops ship can decimate and unpreppared titan. I could literally talk about htis game and compare it to EvE and Minecraft for weeks. But I would rather play it and leave others to make there own choice. I still have an EvE account and activlely play, but there has been more station spinning and Que rolling since this game come out on steam. Its free to try, demo is the full game and you can join a server to see what its like. Its hard in the begining but some basic understanding of EvE will help you adapt quickly. It is more of an RTS then anything else, gameplay wise.

-The best way to play is online with other people. There is no feeling like flying around exploring.
-Finding a huge base, some sick player created ships, and then realizing none of them have faction modules.... So its all yours for the taking.
-Creating turrets to protect your bases and watching someone warp in on top of it and immediatly exploding.
-Creating a large troop of Drones, and releasing them a couple of sectors away from someones base.
-Blowing up someones planet as they beg you to stop.
-Camping someones homebase while offline... with your turret monster.

It just Keeps getting better as I play. At first you are trying to figure otu the mechanics of all the blcoks and how to accomplish what you want to to do. But as I go along I am coming up with really complex ideas and then, overtime testing them.
Magnetic mines, Shotgun turrets and stop effect Lasers, oh my.

You are sleeping on the next great game. All space games will be compared to this in the future.

Buy this game if you like arcadey SpaceSims and building ships and are prepared to deal with lots of bugs and a long and slow development cycle.
Despite it's Minecraft like roots this is not Minecraft, do not expect Minecraft in Space" or that if you can run Minecraft you can run this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very cool sandbox spaceship building game.

I have both this and Space Engineers(SE), and what Starmade lacks in Physics and Graphics it most certainly makes up for in game play depth.
By this I mean, Logic Controllers, the PvE AI, the HUGE Galaxy, the ability to support HUGE ships pretty well but in SE's defense Starmade has less to calculate with relations to Newtonian Physics which SE has.

Putting them side by side, each is better at one thing than the other and they both cater for different crowds.

This game is awesome in that as someone who does not really play on hugely populated servers there is something to do other than chase down 'drifting' abandoned ships with auto turrets that shoot you.

Some features in this game I think are cool:
- PvE AI that are both friend and foe.
- Huge area of space to explore.
- Land / Build on planets.
- Shield generators!
- Decently detailed component system(Reactors, Capacitors, Generators etc)
- Logic Control

All in all for the price tag, if you like Space & Sandbox builders this is an awesome game and would highly recommend it!

Early Access Review

This is a wonderful game with great potential.

The systems that are present are complex enough, and with the latest updates of jump drives, rails, and shipyards, it's pretty much a space ship enthusiast's dream come true. There are plenty of customization options. The weapons system is probably one of the most interesting that I have seen as well as the power systems.

The best part is that everything is MASSIVE. There is no end to it. There are pirates with suitable rewards for pve, entire planets to mine away, stars that will burn you if you get too close and traders who will sell just about anything. There is a strange mix of realism with fake rules that works really well with one another.

The building system is easy to pick up, with more depth the deeper you go. The crafting systems could use some work, but the anaysis of systems is beautifully done. With regular updates and great support, I can see this game going VERY far.

Also, do not call this Minecraft in space. The two games are similar on the surface, But they are in no ways alike.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first heard of StarMade, I was excited, yet weary.  I have often let my emotions run amuck when I encounter a feature list as enormous and tantalizing as the one I read before I began to play this game for free.  To whet your appetite, here's a small portion of features already included in the alpha release.

Build voxel spaceships/stations/settlements of all conceivable shapes or sizes using an absolutely enormous number of blocks.
Easy-to-use interface and building mechanics which make construction an enjoyable experience.
Full multiplayer functionality including factions, player-created economies, and servers which can be customized and modded to create a unique experience on a server by server basis.
A nearly endless universe containing entire galaxies and solar systems all laced with an unchartable amount of planets, asteroids, space stations, pirates, wormholes, and intrigue.
PVP and PVE combat, fight from the helm of your capital ship, cockpit of a fighter, or on foot using a huge and customizable selection of weapon systems against an enemy faction, space pirates, and crabs
Modding support.
Immensely detailed crafting system.
A full set of explorable, player created content and a community which constantly puts out a huge number of original masterpieces and recreations, from TIE Fighters to the UNSC Infinity.
A development team which truly listens to the community and implements player ideas and creations into the game
A roadmap which includes programmable AI, AI creature support, a player-driven quest system, and so much more.
You can build whatever you want, you can fly what you build through a truly endless world, you can do so with large amounts of people.

I can't think of another game that claims to do this much and actually delivers.  Best of all devs consistently release new features and quality of life patches that constantly reinvigorate my interest in this game.



If building your own spaceship and conquering the galaxy sounds at all appealing to you, I recommended you try this FREE alpha version of a fantastic game which is not even near completion yet.  You will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off let me say space is awesome.  What a great setting to host this style of game.

Inspired by Minecraft I believe Starmade is truly a new unique procedural sandbox experience.  The universe is huge, seriously...huge.  They way the game is developed is perfect for exploring star systems mining the planets exploring building factorys etc then moving into new star systems later.  I have 40+ hrs in so far and I am still learning new things. There are so many functional blocks in this game that do incredible things.  Its your imagination truly that limits you in this game as to what you can build.

Building ships is the main focus, building with efficiency at first is very tough to do without doing some sort of research.  Power reactor design is vital, you can build a solid block for a power reactor but building it in different ways grants you more efficiency and more power. ;)

I strongly recommend reading up on the game via wiki or other sources before playing, and play the tutorials.  Lots of you tube videos as well, this is a very large environment with lots going on.  It is amazing the things you can build and achieve in this game.  Just takes time to learn everything and patience.

EDIT: always save your blueprints after or while building.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starmade is a crossover between Minecraft and Eve Online, although only on a very basic level. I'm not a big fan of both of these 2 games, but Starmade is just right.

Whereas Minecraft mostly focuses on construction and survival, Starmade focuses on exploration and expansion. You are thrust into a huge world, and can do anything. You can build your own ships and starbases, land on planets and search for resources, mine asteroids and fight pirates.

Much like Minecraft, Starmade is very focused on construction as well, but in a much more practical way. Upgrading your ship is something you continiously strife to do, and getting the resources required is a job needs doing. Building a ship might seem complicated at first, but a decen tutorial is added in the game, which will guide you through the basics.

In short, this is my experience of Starmade thus far, and im eager to go on and grow. And best of all: It is free. Try the demo (i bought it) and get access to everything Starmade's got to offer. Whether you'll like the game or not: Not a penny has been wasted. I can really give no reason for you not to try.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is good for anyone who likes a simple but expansive type of game. while the only complaint I can make is that the tutorial tends to lag a lot, the game makes up for it with its enless content and detatched and lonly vibe. Starmade starts off by dropping you into a sector with a shop, some money, and very limited resources for building a ship. While building a ship is fun, resources for a new ship are needed if your going off to fight pirates or raid a friend's base. The game essentially forces you into the depths of space, where you only have your crew. Starmade is a game that lets you mold it into what you want it to be, and I highly reccomend buying it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starmade, the game that killed my social life.
10/10 It's ok
(The demo is the full game until the beta comes out)





But if you want a full review...
Don't let my playtime deceive you, i have well over 1000 hours of pre steam play time.
Starmade is a infinite 3D sandbox set in space with an infinite number of planets, stations, asteroids, stars, galaxies and pirates.
You start off with enough blocks to build a small salvager and set off into space. (Well you can also make a nice big gun and attack other players) Then you need to mine asteroids and pretty much anything you find and upgrade your ship. May seem easy but its hard as hell. Pirates will be a constant threat. Teaming up is very important if you don't want your new shiny ship to be blown to the next universe by pirates.
I could go on about how to play but wheres the fun if you already know everything?

Just remember this game is in Early access and its going to change. Better or worse? no one knows. But with the current developers this game is going to go far.


=Here is a little story about when i first met the dev=
Turned starmade on one day. first time in a few weeks. There was a new update message talking about the offical testing server and the new improvments in the prebuild (dev build)
I download the prebuild, join the server, fly into space, and get stuck. on nothing. my controls just didn't respond. about 5 minutes of laughing away in chat and others trying to help (only to glitch backwards, there was a horrible teleporting bug back then) Schema (the dev) joined the game.
so i then asked him for help. He teleported in to see what was wrong and after a bit of silence im stuck aswell..." Minutes later he said he found the bug and updated the prebuild.
And that is the story of how i broke his game and caused one of the first (I think it may have been the first) updates since the test server went up"

Definitely the highest quality voxel space game out there. Space engineers has the graphics crown, however starmade has far and away a better gameplay. The learning curve is worth it and Schema has been a very active developer for years. This gives me faith he won't disappear, barring a disaster.

Want to take over a planet and build a galactic empire? this is the only game you in the world letting you do this, build this, create this, yourself. Everything else similar is far more limited in scope.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Get. This. Game.

It's easy to get into, and deceptively complex.  For example, they have logic blocks, aoe triggers, effects (on pretty much everything from lights to weapons) that you can do all kinds of  things with.  Those are  just a few examples.

The game is freaking huge...not sure if it ever ends tbh...so many sectors in a system, systems  in a galaxy, galaxies in π and you have 42 (Gorilla math was used).

The exploration is like a box of chocolates.  You could find a random shop to buy and sell  things, you could find a pirate station with turrets and ships attacking you, or asteroids, and I even hear you can find  a city but I've yet to find one.  There's planets and asteroids to mine, stations to build,  ships of every kind to make.  There's cloaking, radar jamming, scanning, jump drive (warping / long distance travel), push / pull weapons (tractor beam anyone?), drainers of all types, cannons, missiles, you name it, they probably have it.

You can save your ship designs locally and on servers (multiplayer) and load them onto  another server using blueprints.  Think template that you fill with all the components and when the blueprint has all the parts it  needs you can spawn it.  You can build bases and outposts, or repair undiscovered /  unclaimed stations and  claim them as your own  / build on it.  There's factions (corps  / guilds) and every faction gets to claim 1 home base which is invincible to damage unless  they run  out of faction points (hard to do unless you claim alot of systems or die alot),

Very customizable server settings so each multiplayer server you play on is probably different from every other.  You can customize your singleplayer server.cfg as well if you so choose.

The cons:
This is more on the servers you play on but when there's alot of people it tends to lag / warp.  (It's Alpha).  The initial RAM settings for the game is 1024  which  is really low.  If you are on a  64 bit OS you will want to download the 64 bit Java and change the RAM settings.  You can do this by going to the menu in the launcher > Options > Memory settings

I have 16GB RAM so I changed mine to 8192 1000 1000  and I stopped getting running out of memory errors  in game.  You will also most likely want to disable procedural background if you get alot of lag...caused me several seconds delay getting out of my ships in high pop servers.  All these options can be changed in the launcher, there's also advanced settings in  the launcher.

All in all, this is a very fun game I would highly recommend it and I would buy it again.  I figured sooner or later there wont be a free demo and the price will most likely go up so why not support the devs now and not have to worry about it later on.

Get in a faction with people or with friends as this amplifies the fun factor 10 fold.
11/10 would buy again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll start this review off by pointing out that i have played this game on and off for over a year now. This is one of those rare gems of a game that keeps you coming back for more forever as it is constantly improving through its passionate and dedicated dev team and community.

But more then that. This is a game that has a nearly infinite depth in its mechanics and advanced build modes, logic systems, weapons systems..etc..etc which leaves you with nearly limitless possibilites in which to build whatever ship, base, station you can imagine.

The mulyiplayer aspect is often quite engaging as well with its caring community, factions and moderators that always have interesting events planned and fun things to do, ranging from huge PvP tournements like Blood and Steel where you bring the deadliest machine you can build to wage war against other teams. Along with server bosses or christmas events..etc..etc

Or even something as simple as taking a noob out to fight the pirates for the first time to hear them get excited when they get there first kill in their newly built fighter ship. Or even having to save that same noob later because he jump driven his ship into a star because thay havent learned that they should chart there course a little more carfully when traversing the cosmos.

All of these things add up to a game that is absolutley satisfying , so long as you can muster the patience to overcome the admittedly steep learning curve required to understand the workings of this game competently.

I certainly recommend this game to all who love space, sci fi, sandbox and voxel building games. But must say that it isnt for the faint of heart or those without much patience. But is for those who want to build the baddest mutha of a ship this side of the galaxy has seen

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have mixed feelings for this game so don't bash me for the negative review when I write things I enjoy about this game, thank you.

Overall the game is well built, however I have seen some people having crash issues and I think that is caused by Java having a lack of memory,or something else but I won't discuss that here. ANYWAYS the game is quite big, on some older servers I've joined to ♥♥♥♥ around on, I've seen serveral galaxies explored and on top of that the galaxies themselves are quite large, solar systems (even with a fast ship) can take roughly 20-30 minutes to traverse, longer if pirate infested (which in my opinion there needs to be less pirate stations due to the fact that heat seeking missles dessimate anything that touches them and the pirates and their stations have cannons for days).With that in mind if you have a well built ship which will take ages due to the credit and resource cost if you're crafting (more on that later) getting a ship that can not only hold its own, but fight back against a pirate station is a pain in the ♥♥♥ to get.

Again, if you have a strong ship that goes fast exploration is enjoyable as you watch the planets and stars go by but can get boring after a while and one starts to resort to the use of jump drives more and more.

And for crafting/getting resources, its tedious and grindy especially if you get a large ore haul and try to sell it but can only give each store around 4.5k ore before its completely stocked on it (if this happens sell until you're annoyed and then keep the rest for crafting use) I won't call crafting necesarily fun, its moreso a process of gettings components/ resources together, going afk or mining for a bit, and then coming back to check up on your factory.

However building is truly the highlight of this game, there are several blocks to choose from each of these with their own colors and set shapes (there are 4 i think,being the cube,hepta,slope,corner and maybe something I missed?)With all the shapes and colors available allows for many designs and chassis shapes for ships and allows for one, if given enough time, to make their own unique ship but this is the only thing ,aside from making your own station, that there really is to do since exploring isnt too fun if you ave a long range jump drive and just hop over to a point of interest look at it and go back home.

I wouldn't recommend this game to too many people I know but this game does have a great potential and would like to see where the devs take this game (I'm aware there might be a few things I missed once I get something decent together in my head for those parts I'll write it in)

As of now I give this game a verdict of 4/10 but there is a present potential there and I can't wait to see what will be coming up in future patches.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent the last few hours floating around space in a metal rectangle harvesting ore and crystal with no idea what their for, and the insane thing about it is I'm actualy haveing fun doing it. Haven't even goten to the actual crafting part and already the game has me hooked and its almost zen like in its simplicty, well until I flew into a star. Woopsy! Oh and look out for space pirates too, those guys do not mess around!

Its basicaly Minecraft IN SPACE! But rather then a simple copy-paste job StarMade actualy improves on the formula in a lot of intresting ways. I like how basic crafting tools are built into the inventory itself so your good to go right from the start and its a lot more forgiveing as you don't have to hide in a hole the second it gets dark. Most the people I've encountered in Mutiplayer and on the forms have been nothing but firendly too. Its a fun game but be prepared to earn your greatness, the ship of your dreams wont build itself but hours of gathering and crafting make it all the sweeter when you finaly take out that Space pirate base with a custom-built weapon system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably one of my best game purchases ever. I played it for several hundred hours before finally buying it, and still play it at least 10 hours a week, usually in one session.

The best thing I can say for the game is that I keep forgetting it's early access. It's an amazing game already, and so much is coming still. I think it will eventually fill the promises it made, as well as all the failed ones that most, if not all, space sci-fi games made.

Pros:
-Ships are super-fun to design and build, and ship building is quite in-depth.
-Multiplayer is unbelievably smooth, even with hundreds of ships, small or large, all fighting. That said, your client might need the settings turned down if the ships are big enough. Some people (myself inluded) build ships larger than planets.
-The universe feels alive. They've redone the map, and it is glorious. We have blackholes (wormholes) now too, and a wide variaty of stations, planets and astroids now.
-Despite the above, it manages to highlight how big and empty space really is, which is something i enjoy.
-Docking is quite impressive and flexible, allowing for really cool effects to ships (Such as moving parts).
-THE DEVS LISTEN TO THE COMMUNITY
-Beautiful Graphics (if you like cube games)
-So many awesome features, Im not going to even attempt to list them
-Excelent Configurability
-Good Community
-Good mod support (never tested this, but I've heard no complaints about it)
-Procedurally generated, and absolutly HUGE.
-Probably forgot lots
-Most importantly: The game is always improving, very quickly too. The devs push large quantities of bugfixes and updates every 2 weeks. It's similer to Space Engineers in that respect. Does not feel like an alpha game, really.

Cons:
-They're missing the inverse-corner shape D: I should get around to suggesting this. But I'm too busy playing the game.
-AI still needs work, though it's getting better
-Factions need work as well, though that's coming in a future update
-Very large systems cause non-negligable client lag (negligable server lag though) (I mean multi-thousand block doors, etc)
-Very large ships cause some lag (500x300x300 m3 + on my craptop, but easily 10 - 1000+ times that for good laptops. Virtually unlimited for a solid desktop.)
-Alpha game. Lots of balance changes, content changes, etc.
-Tutorial needs a lot of work - it's outdated. Again. Mostly because of the update frequency.

Very addictive game, good if you like designing spaceships, or space combat. The game also fully supports mining, trading, etc, however, I stick to ship building, because that's my favorite part. This means I can't speak for those systems, but I've heard they're good.

If you want a good example of the game currently, get the demo - it's the full game, and it will be, until the game leaves Alpha. If you want a good idea of where the game is headed, and how it's changed/is changing, check the website, and look at the news" tab.

For some of the best reviews about why I (and many others) like the game

hoursPlayed: was plenty. At the moment

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starmade is a wonderfully looking vowel game where you're stuck near a shop in distant space needling to create a ship and persue you future. You can be a miner and refine materials, you could be a fighter and salvage enemy ships, or you could just buy things with the credits you have. And if you prefer a non survival approach you can use the cheats to get infinite blocks and build whatever you can imagine! There is no limit.

I've had a really good time on this game, singlplayer and multiplayer. But try the demo first.:D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is to address the people having performance issues. I'm running on an older i7 2600, with 8gb of ram. I have no FPS or lag problems whatsoever, unless some asshat in a 2km ship is trying to breed with a planet.

First, make sure you know your computer specs, I recommend having at least:

6gb of system memory
i5 3450.
GTX550 or equivilant
If you use intel graphics, dont. Save yourself the pain.

1: 1 GB of ram allocated is NOT enough for this game, get 64bit java and increase it immediately in the launcher (options > memory settings) - I use 6gb normally, but you should be okay allocating 3-4.

2: Disable shadows to greatly increase your FPS, it is highly inefficient currently, and unless you mod the game, the draw distance sucks.

3: There are lots of options available, only mess with the ones you know, if you want to find out what something does, go here https://starmadedock.net/chat/ log in and ask the community - we're mostly helpful.

4: If the tutorial hates you, and you can't complete it, again go to the above link and ask the community! We will be happy to help.

As for the game itself, it's incredible fun, if you like building ships, the largest ship you can build without rendering going wonky is about 4072m long/high/wide, with the core being placed in the center.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The good:
- A tutorial - as in there actually is one and it's moderately useful
- Various texture packs built in to the client so it looks less Minecraft-like
- You can build *massive* ships and there is a decent selection of utlity modules

The middling:
- OK build tools - far better than Minecraft, maybe worse than Space Engineers
- The star systems are basically all the same - pick any one and you can find every resources you need, no reason to explore
- There are NPC enemies, and they will pester you, but don't expect to be challenged by cleverness.  Tenacity perhaps...

The bad:
- The crafting interface.  Yes it has a filter to search, but no categorization.  Browsing a small list is painful.
- The UI elements.  Ok, this is early access, some of it is likely developer art.  Recommend these guys go look at Space Engineers for a better example of UI.
- The flight model.  Flight games *scream* for a joystick and rudder system - this system only supports one controller at a time so unless your stick does everything, it comes out to be much less useful.  Using a keyboard and mouse to fly anywhere near a planet is basically an exercise in frustration - get a gamepad at the minimum for when you step inside a ship.

This game is like Minecraft in space, but without so much grinding trying to find resources (they are in fact very easy to get once you build a salvage ship - you will spend more time waiting for the resources to process than actually acquiring them.)  If you like *building* things, you will enjoy this game.  If you like *fighting* things, your enjoyment will probably be short-lived.  If you like *exploring*, you're enjoyment will also be short-lived.

But it's still Early Access, so give it some time.  It will no doubt improve (just see how far Space Engineers has come along.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played a little over 8 hours so far and I'm simply floored by how cool this game is. The game's Minecraft like take on spaceflight and spaceship/station building is simply fantastic. While my current ship building ability is akin to a 3 year old drawing on the wall with crayons, I'm simply in love with the full gamut of things available to build with. Looking on Youtube you can find users who've built fleets of Titan class ships that look absolutely gorgeous and wonderfully showcase what this game can let you build.

The first ship I built was simply a small cube. It was hideous, but after a run in with a pirate station (which chased me for a fairly long ways) I had to rebuild. I landed on a planet and mined the only thing I could see: lava. I wondered what I could do with lava and found out that while it's useless for crafting, it makes a seriously bright ship. So I built a ship out of lava. After watching some videos on youtube I realized that I'd just wasted a significant amount of time doing nothing, and I built a better ship purely for mining. It's ugly as sin, but it can demolish an asteroid in about 2 minutes, so I'm happy with it for the time being. After I mine a bit more I'm going to dive into crafting, then I'll make a really big ship. (Currently mine doesn't have an inside) I'm also hoping that (since I know how to use Photoshop) I can possibly contribute to some of the texture packs on http://starmadedock.net

So far I haven't recommended any game to my friends as much as I have this one. I already bought the 4 license pack and hope the developers keep on chugging away on this, it has so much potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been a player since pre alpha, the game has an awesome UI. The ship building is fairly simple to get started. The game shows you how to make a basic space clunker, and how to mine the environment, and you will find it is easy to get moving.
The problem lies in how spread out some of these planets and resources are, ESPECIALLY in multiplayer.

The second main issue is the clunky launcher and massive memory/fps issues. I have a very respectable gaming setup, and I am always crashing, you need to have 64 bit java, and the correct memory values input into the game launcher, the one before you actually start the game. Why the game has essentially two launchers is ridiculous. The game online suffers from the same problem Minecraft does online, you have to hike 50000000000 miles/galaxies away to get started because everything is claimed or you will get ganked.

So if you are looking for a fun space sandbox, look elsewhere. If you are looking for Minecraft in space, look elsewhere.
I cannot recommend this game at this time.

Edit: At this time" Meaning I am AWARE its not at release yet."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, after I fixed the game thanks to the superb support staff at Starmade, I must say I am exited for my future endeavours in this huge universe. If you are having the player drifting problem, follow these steps.




unfortunately it looks like your installation is broken.

The best and easiest way to fix it, is to create a new folder and start with a fresh automatic installation of starmade.

To do this,
browse to your hard-disk (C:) and create a new folder.
I suggest using the path:
C:\Starmade
however, any path not in a protected area from windows will work. ('Programs', 'Desktop', 'Download' and 'My Files' are places that can cause problems. Antivirus scanners block access or scan every file-access and slow down your game without a good reason.)

Now place a fresh downloaded launcher from the official download page

http://star-made.org/download

in that folder and start it.

Now select the correct path in the Launcher:



enter the correct path into the opening dialog:



Hit OK and
let it install the latest version by clicking on:



in the Launcher.

Your starmade should work now.
If not please add log from that installation.

Open:
C:\Starmade\StarMade\logs

and send in all files you see in that folder.
We will check for the source of the problems then.
(Yes it may sound like a fraud, but this is the only way we have a reliable log, where we have a good knowledge about the load orders and events happening.)


- Andy Püttmann

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like 4x RTS games? Well this is essentially a 4x RTS played from the perspective of a single minecraft astronaut.

When you get past the ship creation and crazy engineering aspects of this game, it feels like an MMO 4x RTS where you build an empire (faction) and claim entire solar systems for resources.

This game is insanely good if you can get over the minecraft graphics and bugs and experience the game for what it is, a crazy genre bender of MMO/voxel sandbox/Space Sim/4x RTS.

I HIGHLY recommend this game to anybody who is even remotely interested in building ships/space stations, open world corpse looting hardcore PvP or space RP.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you love minecraft this is pretty much the next step.  Still needs alot of work but the devs are keeping up with updates and what there working on.  But if youve always wanted to build your own space craft and fly arcoss the galaxy this is it.  Construction consists of more than your basic square block, theres several tetra shapes and wedges to give a craft or object a more round apearence.  Collecting blocks (mining) is very easy and quick depending on how you do it.  Lots of cool stuff to play with like missiles, sheilds, automatic turrets and AI's.  Graphics arent quite there yet.  Lowest setting some blocks have more detail than they do on the highest setting but it should get fixed(i would think). But ive had alot of fun just playing in single player but it can get boring by yourself.  But thats why theres multiplayer.  Overall its a really good sandbox for the stage its in.  If it follows the minecraft dev line there will always be new content and fun stuff being added and worked on.  Well worth the cheap price!
