reviewText:
Early Access Review

I full heartedly support this game. I've been playing it since learning about it, about .4x release or so, back on Minecraft when i asked a few of my buddies about any other games like it. And by far this game TRUMPS Minecraft when it comes to sheer size, exploration and sense of seclusion.

The game itself is a massive sandbox for those wondering about it. It allows you to build practically *anything* from houses,  hovercraft and mining vessels, to fighters, gigantic mining stations and factories! The game itself requires a very good computer to run (a 400$ Acer like me, cannot handle the newer patches to the game for instance. I'll be able to play the game in February in earnest when i build my new gaming rig :) )

This game also supports exporting projects from 3-dimensional tools like Blender as blueprints! which then can be implemented into the game and 'purchased' with in-game currency. This helps when you see a 3D model and think if only i could fly it" ;)

Combat is heavily based upon your ability to protect your 'baby' (your ship or creation) and it gives you a VERY wide variation in weapons and protection possibility! From mobile sentries to stationary defense platforms you can protect worlds
date: sectors or even entire quadrants! The game is literally stagnated only by YOUR creativity. YOU control the fun. YOU control the environment for the most part. And as the game says in the description
recommended:
it is YOUR universe.



Personal experience with the game:[/i] I first started up on a mini-server called Illusive with 4 buddies of mine. we made a faction called "The Fringe". We hung around the spawn for a couple days
hoursPlayed: learned how to build basic ships and began an adventure out into the void which lead us nearly a THOUSAND sectors away! it took us nearly an hour to reach our base... what started out as a derilect NPC shop out of supplies. We branched off
voteText:
made 7 massive combat vessels over the course of 2 months and made 6 sentries capable of holding off the average A.I pirate (special made ships which turned out to become more aggressive over the years.) Our three flag ships....

The Leviathan: a massive Dreadnaut carrier (blender model i made) designed to carry 120 small fighters with 2 lasers. With 1k engines and a little over a million shield the beast didn't move fast.. but it could take a beating.  Leviathan picture[thesurviver.deviantart.com]

The Liberty: A smaller ship
helpfulPercent: designed to be made in bulk as carriers
votesHelpful: support vessels
votesTotal: combat cruisers. These were going to become the backbone of an A.I based defense fleet of about 15 ships. Lead by my buddie's "Shadow" Liberty shown here.  Shadow Liberty[thesurviver.deviantart.com]\n\nThe Behemoth: A project i was working on for nearly 2 months and ended up halting because the size was killing my frame rate (at least until next month ;) ) And at nearly 18million it was not going to be something i could simply spawn in. With that in mind i made this beast a floating battlestation. With 6 guns capable of a mind-boggling 1mil damage output per second
votesFunny: a shield of nearly 100million and a battery chamber that engulfed the inner body of the ship
commentsCount: it wouldn't be going down without a fight Unfortunately my computer couldn't run ascreenshot without crashing the game once i got the second 3 barrel cannon on the ship
column16:
so here it is in the prototype stages Behemoth wrapup part 1[thesurviver.deviantart.com] after the first month this is what had been made....


Another ship
column17: which i unfortunately do not have a picture of
column18: is an even BIGGER ship that a member of the Fringe we picked up later had built. It held 18 turrets on either side
column19: with a gun that lined the middle of the dual hull ship with a damage output that made my ships sound like a laughing stock. He spent 7 months building it up. The ship was called the Keldon. I have a partially damaged blueprint of the ship personally saved and will hopefully be able to repair it. However sitting at a whopping 128million to spawn it? i'll be working on it in singleplayer. lol"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game caught my eyes while I was browsing games to buy in the steam shop.  I saw the trailer and I bought it right after that.

I have probably spent 95% of my playing experience in singleplayer.  I didn't have any help from real players so this review will be in that perspective

First, I'll go with the cons.  You can get pretty lost in the launcher for the game.  Also, if you don't set your memory to a good level and don't set the graphics to a level your computer can handle, you might not even be able to run the game at a good speed (or at all).  There is also a bit of a learning curve to the game.  For the first few days you play, you will probably spend just as much time playing the game as you will watching youtube videos trying to figure out how to make things work properly.  As for the youtube videos, a lot of them are a bit outdated, and finding a recent video can be difficult.  There's also not a lot of content when it comes to singleplayer, but that's because this game was built more for the multiplayer experience.  Although there are many planets and systems, they are very similar to each other so the only thing that makes you explore is having to move to the next system to find more resources.  For where the game is at, I think the build mode is pretty great, but it could use some tweaks to make it faster and easier.  For example, I find it a bit tedious to have to go into 'advanced edit' and having to press an arrow 5-10 times and look at a tiny picture of the selected piece, trying to find the right orientation of the block you're trying to place everytime I switch to a different part of a ship.  And I find that most of the time, I get the wrong orientation because in some lightings it's very difficult to tell which direction the block is facing in the tiny picture if it's all one color.  I think a system where you could click and hold the mouse button then move your mouse in different directions to change the orientation would make building 1000% easier (maybe they already have an easier way and I don't know about it).  That's all I really have for cons.

For the pros, this game is just amazing.  If the thought of building your own ship and scavanging the galaxy for resources excites you, this is the game for you.  If you want to build a ship with a ridiculous amount of salvage modules so you can mine to the core of a planet in the click of a button, you can do that.  If you want to build extravagant space stations where you can store all your ships, you can do that.  If you want to kill pirates and plunder their stations, you can do that.  All this I'm explaining is still only scratching the surface.  Once you get into multiplayer, there are factions you can join and wars you can fight.  This game is so fun and is only going to get better with every update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only just purchased this game so my hours on the demo do not reflect here, but new non the less and my opinion should be taken with a ladel of salt.

In one sentence; The integrity and feel of Minecraft's Tekkit mod in space with the galatical proportions and procedural generation of worlds and galaxies akin to Spore. Hard to sum this game up in one short sentence.

This will take time to reach a point where you are comfortable with all the features in the game spanning the crafting side of things and most things just take time in single player because, well space has a lot of space.

I'm playing on a Mac (eat me, idgaf) so I obviously ran into some errors while trying to play this game, like a buggy tutorial. I managed to over look that and educated myself through youtube on how this great gem works and found plenty of support there. (Yogcast has a series on this I hear, so that's worth checking it out if you like their previous works.)

SO will take time due to high learning curve, great for voxel fans and great for space and sci-fi enthusiasts.

I don't have the time for this game but It's nice.

(If you're working a job with plenty hours, this game may frustrate you with the time base commitment needed to overcome the steep learning curve. Download the demo first, see what it's about and then consider supporting the team if you believe in this cause. I have a full time job, starting me off on a pretty disappointing and frustrating foot, but worth it later on.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an excellent game if you like space, exploring, trading, fighting, building.

It's a voxel style game(Minecraft) so you can build you're spaceships/spacestation/bases however you like.  There are loads of blocks to choose from and includes a build helper for shapes and symmetry and multi place options.

The flight mechanics are good,  Astronaught flight can be clumsy at times, but not bad.  Camera options are mostly good but need more added to them.

I'm completely addicted to the game right now.   The few downsides i've noted are already being worked on.  The gui is a bit dated but will be changed for next patch.  I think the map view could use some work as well.

I %100 Reccommend this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is so close to being an absolutely amazing game. Currently, without a more complex/dynamic NPC faction system, my biggest problem is that there isn't enough to do in single player. I don't have a ton of time to invest in playing on servers, so I think that solves that problem, just not for me. Another problem I have is that there are a TON of systems and mechanics to learn, and perhaps they're not the most intuitive. I haven't played in months, but the crafting system was a bit confusing for me back then, and more stuff has come in since then.

Now, done with the negatives...

This is a great game. Open world? Not good enough, try open space. The building system is fantastic, and you should check out some of the ships and stations people have made- they're absolutely stunning, nothing short of spectacular. The combat mechanics are fun and exciting, and there's a lot of room for ships of different combat and non-combat roles.

I can only say GET THIS GAME. It's a ton of fun, and the progress made over the past year is phenomenal. The devs are doing a great job and like I said- this game is just a couple features and improvements away from being something truly special.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has improved quiate a lot since my inital review a year ago. I can now recommend it. You can call this minecraft in space, bit it's now a lot more than that. It can be a MMO, but with built-in anti-greifing  to some extent (only your faction home is protected). Faction permissions have improved quite a bit to prevent bad faction members from stealing resrouces and ships.

Also it's a lot of fun. Build whatever you want, build elevators, huge hanger doors, tiny ships, huge ships. The universe is big enough that you can find your own litte corner of the galaxy not to be bugged, or, fly off to a far off galaxy if you want.

You can now have your own fleet of ships that will fight to defend you, mine, or fly off to whever you command them (in fact, fleet orders can be used as a kind of slow auto-pilot).  The role of NPCs are being expanded. If you're running your own sever, you can write your own NPC scripts and load them for custom game experience.

When you first play this game, keep in mind that block placement matters for many system blocks (esp. power and weapons). Usually due to the coplexity of the game, young children don't play it as much, so it's generally a more mature community. If you've grown out of Minecraft, this is for you.

Also, you can play the game for free as of now, and can lauch it direclty wihout using steam (which is how I normally play). The only thing is, most servers WON'T allow you to connect unless you've bought the game-- so go buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hi everyone
I was bored and in search of a new game and i came across this diamond.
When i frist started the game i didnt know what to do, but it was not too difficult to get into the game.
Mastering was a bit more diffucult. First i had a server running on my comp with 2 of my friends. It worked really well with an good i7. Then we had a dedicated server.

It was great fun to climb the learning curve from a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ship to planetary harvester and doomstar which can kill a planet with one shot. My gaming time was before buying the game -> just 11 hrs. Now we dont play much because so much new stuff is added  (which is very good) and we want to wait a little bit.

I thought about cons alot. i hatet the non newton flight model (->i like it when things are floating through space forever) but now we have it in here as well and i love it.
So it is pretty hard judge before the game is not finished.

My conlusion -> Play the whole game for free (DEMO). You can not do wrong. And dont let you scare off in first 5min.
You will miss a lot of fun.

A factory guide ingame.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love the possibilities with this game, and I recommend it to any sci-fy fan. There is a learning curve with this game, but I consider it a game worth learning.

Some things you can do in StarMade...
You can mix and match weapon systems and support systems for cool useful effects. You can save the ship you just built as a blueprint, build a ship yard, and have it make more ships. You can design functional turrets.  The logic system in the game is stunning, and with it you can make moving platforms, combine logic systems, and do other amazing things. You can explore massive galaxies, connect star systems by warp gates, raid pirate bases, mine asteroids or entire planets.

There are many things I am still learning about this game, and some small details I want fixed, but I am loving StarMade as it is, and look forward to its continued development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TRY THE DEMO, THE GAME IF FULLY FREE WHILE IN ALPHA, THE DEMO IS CURRENTLY THE FULL GAME CLIENT AND NOT PURCHASE IS REQUIRED TO PLAY THE FULL GAME AT THIS TIME. PAYING IS FOR THOSE WHO WITH TO BACK THE GAME DURING EARLY ACCESS.

EDIT 16/5/2016
I love this game, i originally played it from their website when it was much more primative, and i loved it then and i love it even more now.

The developers for this game, are doing a fantastic job, i love this game for the ship and base building, i have not dabbled too much in the MP aspect, but the PvP battles i have seen can become pretty epic.

Think of this as a Sci-Fi minecraft style game, you have a full galaxy to explore, you can land on and build on planets and take over space stations and even claim solar systems for your faction.

The games main focus is the building your dream structure and ships and hunting pirates and possibly other players.
The game has bugs but it is very solid, but none i have found so far really impact gameplay.

like mentioned above you do not need to pay to play this game during the alpha phase, so there is no harm in trying it.
The game does use java and can get pretty heavy on system resources, but the video options are huge.

If your interested give it a shot, the downloader is only a few hundred meg and thats it.
This game is perfect for having other friends playing with you.

--------

I see a LOT of reviews of people with sub par machines who still seem to think 8gb ram is still a lot and 32bit OS is still ok, or a dual core processor is still viable, and complaining that this game runs poorly, DUH you machine sucks, the game is a BIG ram and CPU ♥♥♥♥♥, its the nature of the game rendering SO MUCH at once, you cannot expect the game to be 100% optimised, as it is still in heavy development, and much is changing over time, it run a lot better then it did a few months back, and its only getting better.

Updates are rather slow, but they are meaningful.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far for what the game is, its pretty darn good! Not that much to do other than build ships and  mine resources. Should be played with friends or multiplayer for sure though!

The Goods:
- World size
- Ship building system is awesome, build anything and fly it
- Wide variety of ship building blocks
- Blueprint sytem allows you to build saved ships by collecting the required blocks. This way you can download cool ships, and collect the required stuff and create it. Good for if your not the best ship builder :P me...

The Bads:
- Clonky UI
- AI
- Sounds are needed for sure

Overall, I think its definitaly a game to get now, I can see in the future this game being a awesome game.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay to start off, this is a really fun game! It's like Space Engineers and Minecraft fused together. You get to build awesome ships and spacestations, fly around a huge galaxy filled with wormholes, planets, asteroids, and your common space pirates. Pirates can be very annoying due to their massive amount of space stations and ships. Their space stations, if not discovered, will appear unknown on the map, but once you find one, you'll want to turn tail and run... that is unless you have a great ship.
In the game, there are shops to buy parts for whatever build you're making. Though if you have a lot of loot from asteroids, pirates, or whatever, you might make the merchants go bankrupt... But don't worry, there are plenty of other shops out there.
Also I forgot to mention you are able to mine things! Asteroids are filled with minerals that you could craft or simply sell. Not mentioning you can mine planets, and get mega butt ton of awesome stuff!
I bet you're wondering about wormholes from the first paragraph. Do not go towards one! If you are in the sector of a wormhole, it will suck you in, and spew you out into a part of the galaxy. They don't as much hurt you, they can just get really annoying.
Finally we have Pros VS Cons:

Pros:
-Awesome Universe
-Buld Awesome stuff
-Many things to do
-You don't need a awesome gaming PC to play (Unless we're dealing with planets)

Cons:

-Planets are very laggy and in some cases crash games
-The Pirates don't play fair and auto-aim to the most important peices of your ship
-If you don't place your turret or ship core right, you could get out of your ship (Like outside your ship)
-Some players are trolls and will mess with you and your stuff

But in overall you can have fun with friends, make a faction, work together, and maybe hyave a war with another friend! This game is great for people who like to have fun, Sci-Fi fanatics, and people who love to build reall cool things!
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAwesome!! 5 Stars!!! Minecraft in space but much more fun. Easy to mine your first few million credits in about 2 hours of single player gameplay. Ship builds are limited to your imagination, the whole universe is. If you like building and creating your own game than this is for you.  Legos in space!!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDid you ever play eve and want to control your own ship? Want to make your own ship? Want to build a base with automated defenses? want to mine faster? Ever play mine craft and wish you could go to space and kill people. Ever want to own the galaxy? Ever want to have fun with friends? This is thegame for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's minecraft with the following exceptions:

It's in space (space that has planets you can land on), angles, factions, more (but more visually similar) resource types, better lighting, steeper learning curve, vehicles, and more.

Basically, imagaine if you were to draw a line connecting EVE online and Minecraft. This game would sit about in the middle of that line.

I defiantely suggest it, after getting past the learning curve, I think I'm enjoying this more than minecraft.

The four biggest downsides though
1. Early game, things take much longer than minecraft. Travel distances can take a long time, and jump drives only go so far.
2. There's a lot less secrets. No nether, no real dungeons buried down deep (at least not that I've found)
3. Many resources are a bit spread out... space is very empty.
4. Community sizes are still small. However, this is something that will hopefully change with time.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game for quite a while before steam accessed it. I stopped playing for a while and then when browsing through steam, wallah, StarMade. I was like, Uh Mah Gerd, I have to get this. So I bought it and relearned what they changed.

Starmade is a space sandbox where you have to pretty much build your ship from scratch, build up resources, build another, bigger, better ship, farm pirates, buy supplies, build another bigger, better ship... get into crafting, realize it's better to farm and sell pirate loot, etc. etc. Your ships can go in any direction you want them to, they can be the fastest, the ship that packs the most punch, a healing ship, a power regen ship, whatever your imagination can design within the confines of this game.

If you can get a group of friends together you can make a local server fairly easily, FOR FREE, or you can join one of the many official servers that, from what I've seen, are well populated. On these servers you can hold grand battles, roleplay, whatever you can come up with. I personally like building ships, host a game, and have some of my friends build ships as well and see who has the better vessel. The game also allows you to save and upload ships to different servers, which can be handy when your 'Baby' gets blown to smitherines.

If you don't like some of the options for your hosted or singleplayer world you can change it easily in the game files, like how many credits shops have and can recharge, or the universal speed limit. I would recommend looking up some of the options before changing, because at this stage in the game you don't know if changing a certain option will make that specific world unplayable, but the developers put a warning in the options notepad stating whether or not the option is safe to change, and they do tell you the min. and max. variables that are allowed for that option.

As of now the game is in it's early stages, there are much to fix and add, and fix again. So don't be expecting the most perfect game, that has a lot of content. It is not as buggy as when I first started playing, so I am glad for that.

I would reccomend this game to any sci-fi, space building, crafting, co-op loving, kitten adoring... did I mention space, gamers out their.


9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yeah, I know, I have not played it much, but this game is amazing!

Over many years I kept searching for an endless space sandbox/survival game where you can go fly around galaxies (That are actually really, really big, not just a few star systems thrown together that is called a 'galaxy' by a game).
StarMade truly delivers. Make your own 3 block micro ship or make hundred thousand block ships! You will spend hours exploring a big sector of a single galaxy, when there are around a hundred big sectors in each galaxy, maybe even more!

Yeah, also, unlike those other modern space sims, there is no loading screens between transitions to other places. It is all physical space that you have to go through. Only the visuals are buggy slightly (but very rarely). The game devs are heavily involved in the community (from what I have seen) No waiting 3 months for a bug fix update! To find a game that I described above, that also has regular updates and a helpful dev team is extremely rare...

10/10!
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game the day I tried it, before it was ever on steam. It has so much potential as a sandbox space game that I can't help but get a little excited when I see it in my library. Now that it is on steam I have a lot of faith in the development.

I do have the occasional bug. However, the game is solid. The physics are pretty good around planets and the multiplayer aspect of the game can be pretty fun. The AI turrets are a solid part of space combat but the AI ships have something to be desired in terms of how far they will go away from where you start them when AI enemies come for you.

The combat itself is pretty straight forward and can be pretty entertaining, there is nothing like hiding in your factions home planet or station while your AI Turrets take out the enemy while viewing it all through a glass wall. BTW when you are running a server you can have the game spawn as many ships of any saved design as you want.

The game is neat-o.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been a fan of Minecraft for many years, and have played many spin off games. None have come close to Minecraft, and Minecraft with Mods just seemed like all you could ever need when it came to games in it's genre.

However, there were things that Minecraft, even with Mods, never did perfectly. For example, I built Ships in Minecraft and enjoyed it, but they weren't the best. First, they were fixed in place. May as well be a building, even if it was a pretty good looking building at that. Second, they didn't really DO anything. They looked cool and you could walk around them, but that's about it. I mean, you could add redstone functions and stuff but they really didn't have a purpose. Also, once Minecraft or the mod packs were updated, you would have to restart your world from scratch or try migrating your saved world to the new server. Good luck with that!

Enter StarMade- a game which does so many things right. If you ever found yourself wanting to build ships from scratch like in Minecraft, this is your game. Period. It's not just the fact you can make ships block by block- you can actually FLY them. I mean, through space. You can add functions to them, such as shields, thrusters, doors, turrets, lights, and armor. You can add Weapons like Missiles, Beam Lasers, Cannon lasers, pulse weapons... You have to build power for your ship, and you can make use salvage beams to gather materials. You can dock to other ships or space stations, meaning you can effectively have carrier ships. Ships have artificial gravity, and best of all- it's all multiplayer as well.

How cool is it that you can build a carrier ship with your friends onboard, have them fly off in fighter jets as you pilot the large carrier ship? As cool as it gets if you ask me. You can also build space stations and explore small planets with their own gravity. You can use black holes to travel across the galaxy, and there is infinite space to explore. Of course, don't forget space pirates you can fight.

While the game is early access, you get a very amazing experience for the money. Crafting isn't the same as Minecraft, but it is still fun. The core of the game is about making your own fun, but there is a growing community of people and plenty of online servers you can explore.

While there are of course cons to the game. Some may find the lack of clear goals a turn off, or how their is an initial learning curve with how the ships work, however, If you can make your own fun building with friends, salvaging, and attacking pirates, and aren't afraid of looking online if you have a quick question, than you are in the right place. While the game can use more content, there is plenty here to warrant getting into the game now as there is plenty to keep you busy. Money well spent.

If you are still on the fence, I would like to tell you about the Blueprint system. You can save Blueprints of ships you build, allowing you to create the same ship again, even on other servers. You can even take ships you create in solo play to multiplayer servers, or take ships you create from old versions of StarMade and play them as StarMade is updated. I have not lost a ship through all the updates we have had in the last year thanks to the blueprint system- compared to Minecraft where I have had to restart servers and lose everything every time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Truly a great building/space exploration game. As an early access game, you would expect it to have lots of glitches, bugs, or flaws, but surprisingly, StarMade has almost none, except for one where at certain angles players and npc's appear invisible. The only thing really that makes this game an early access game is that there are some gameplay mechanics and items that havent been implemented yet, such as certain items not having implemented fuel usage, but they are going to add that in future updates. All I can really say about this game is that i trust the developers to make this game even greater as it is now, which I am sure that they are going to do.

I r8 9/10
Pros:
+Doesnt seem like a minecraft rip off at all, except for the obvious blocky and pixely design of the game
+Huge amounts of variation, you can make almost any ship you can dream of, big or small
+Nearly infinite universe, There are thousands of things to discover, you can claim entire planets and solar systems for your faction (a clan of sorts)
+Tons of suff to do, you'll almost  ever get bored, as you can mine, build, travel, hang out, and have huge faction against faction space battles in huge space battleships
+Friendly community, many players will help you if you have questions and dont know what to do
+Modding, I haven't really done this yet, as I only got the game several days prior to writing this review, but i have heard from several other friends there is some great stuff you can get from mods
+Lots of servers, there are only several more than 100 servers, but with an infinite universe and high player caps on most servers, all you'll really need is one (One good server is Freaks R Us, there are several players that play on that server a lot that will help you if you need it

Cons: (Will not be listing stuff not implemented yet because it's in early access)
- Long distance between planets and shops, making it a drag to go to a different planet or space station
-Space Pirates, the main enemy NPC, is pretty overpowered unless you have a massive ship armed and ready. DO NOT approach pirate stations soon after starting the game in single or multiplayer
-kind of a grind to salvage and sell natural resources for credits to buy ship/building parts


Thats my review of StarMade, the space exploration/building/pvp, I bought this game out of a Humble bundle for $1, so you cant really go wrong, and i recommend that you do the same, its still on the humble bundle website for 2 more days at the time of this review, so if you want to, go get it for $1.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not your usual sandbox, it takes a bit of understanding to actually enjoy this game. First of all it is recommended to finish tutorial as it covers the basics of game. Secondly, have patience and try to understand the simple mechanism of computer + modules, which is the core mechanism to build systems on a ship. Once you are done, you should be able to build your self a basic ship with basic working systems. With time you will discover more like how to make efficient systems, use logic to create complex systems and more.

All in all its a great sandbox and it can be your go to space sandbox, sci-fi rpg (if you have a couple of your friends with you) or can be your space ship design simulator :P. There are alot of servers available for multiplayer and most of the community is supporting with exceptions of few jerks. With my more than 700 hours (80+ hours in purchased one & 650+ hours on demo) I will definitely recommend this game but also will suggest to try demo beforehand.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Admittedly I will be a bit biased in this response as I am helping in the development for this game. However I will give the most honest answer I can.

It's been far too long since I should have made this post. I have been playing StarMade consistently for over a year and discovered it far before that. (There is a good chance I have hundreds of hours but I don't use steam to launch the game so that is surely incorrect in my hours played) Since then it has undergone massive changes and very much so in a positive direction. Visually and gameplay wise it continues to become an amazing game. This review will be from the perspective of an experienced player around December 2015

Graphics: This isn't any Star citizen, nor is it Space Engineers (a game it is often compared to) when it comes to graphics. The universe is cubed. It follows the trend set fourth by Minecraft (despite being planned long before MC made it's debut). I must say however, I never had such faith in the graphics of a voxel game. Even with shaders installed and a great texture pack, Minecraft can hardly come close to the visuals of StarMade. This is due to the use of built in normal, emission and specular maps. Additionally it has some very decent shadows as well. Like much of the rest of the game, a lot of this is configurable.

Scale: The universe is massive. Often times I will hear new players remark on how large a ship is. To me the same ship may be small. The feeling of walking around a kilometer long spaceship is awesome and getting to that point in the game is worth the money alone. Space itself is split up neatly into grids, which allow this universe to exist at this scale. From sectors to systems to galaxies, you could spend your entire time flying and never see the same stars again. The only area where scale is lacking is planets. These objects often sit under a kilometer in radius. That said, I know it is intended to bump up the scale where possible. Despite pushing a java game beyond what is possible, we will eventually reach it's limit's. At least for now those limits have yet to be reached.

Setting: The game is purely science fiction based. You can if you want turn on options for a more realistic experience, however the idea is that creativity should flourish and it should be fun to play. The universe is a bit empty right now, however rest assured. I myself am personally working on various assets that will be in the game and additionally we will see mechanics introduced that turn this into a bustling dynamic universe. Aliens, flora, space derelicts, cosmic anomalies. All of this is planned. Some of it is already in the game!

Building: Building has never been simpler. All blocks and materials are 1 cubic meter. I think this is the advantage this game has over similar titles. There is no need to build a large chunky machine that serves a specific purpose. Or to place it in a way on your build so that it actually functions. You can have a ship that makes just about no sense, but it will still work. If you like it, why should the game punish you for that? Additionally there are crazy awesome build tools. Templates for shapes, copy/paste, undo/redo, and symmetry planes just to name a few. All of this easily accessible from your ship.

Crafting: Crafting is simple and complex at the same time. There are 24~ resources that produce just about every block in the game, most of which you will eventually find a place for on your ship. These resources are fed into factories and can be automated and made more efficient.

Combat/gameplay: There is a lot to learn here and it will likely be where a new player will get stuck. Combat can be exciting, however I expect balancing as well as new features to be added till release. There are multiple approaches though; shield tanking, armor tanking, dps based. You can use missiles, lasers, cannons, or turrets or combinations of all of this. You can install jump drives to escape, you can install jump inhibitors to prevent escape! No idea is too crazy for StarMade and a lot of science fiction based features have made their way into the game simply because they are awesome.

I imagine learning how to play the game will be the hardest part for any new players. Learning to play is worth it however. The game's demo is free but will not be updated beyond beta or public release. As the game approaches full release the price will increase so now is the time! Take the time to learn and see what is possible and you will be getting your money's worth!

TLDR; Easy building with great tools. Simply yet deep crafting system that makes sense. Massive universe and massive scale. Anything in the realm of science fiction is a reality and may become a part of the game as it develops!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions after a short play session...

I like the overall idea. I like the concept of flying literally great distances to planets I can SEE in the distance and get there and land on them. I like building your own ship and I also really like the overall look of the game.

I do not enjoy the controls. I do not like the many crashes involving my java. I do not appreciate the sound issues. If you have windows 8 the sound probably isn't going to work unless you do the workaround (which the devs put in the launcher for you). I like that. Don't like the fact that it is happening and I have to fix it myself though. Although being so early in the development I understand there will be things like this.

I did not play this game before it hit steam but I've seen and heard the stories. Planets used to be rounder and gravity was less goofy. However that wasn't overly noticeable and it is MUCH easier to land on planets when the sides are hexagonal and flat.

My BIGGEST issue comes from having to tweak my game settings drastically do make it work. I put everything up on ultra and the draw distance was massive. I have I think 16gigs of ram right now and a GTX770 with a i7 processor. The game lagged hard during some of the loading phases. This isn't THE top of the line, but it's at least in the top 10-15%. I can run anything on ultra with no issues right now and seeing this game come to a crashing halt kinda sucks. I haven't googled this or anything so there very well may be something Im doing wrong   =)    if anyone knows you can comment on this but I might find out by the time you do.

Overall through the glitches the game is pretty damn enjoyable. Being able to construct a spaceship in game is super easy to do and the controls are listed right on the screen unless you disable them which is a big help when you're new.

Please bear in mind that the game is still pretty early in the development phase and it WILL have bugs and it WILL feel incomplete but I as of right now I kind of like it as a way to get my exploration fix in."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I currently have a love-hate relationship with StarMade. It's a fantastic game and concept, but as an early access game it is very buggy. Three hours of work going into building a huge battleship could be lost because the game crashes due to some miscelaneous error or some glitch occurs on a planet you're landed on and launches your ship 3 sectors over while you're still on the planet, stranded.

I have thus far rage-quit twice due to these errors, swearing I wouldn't waste my time again by playing this game. Only to come back home from work dying to play it again because of all the ideas you'll get thinking of ways to arrange your hangar, or what weapons you'll place where, or what station or faction you'll attack next. I can imagine them fixing many of the bugs and creating an amazing universe to explore in the future of this game, there's just so much flexibility they have with it.

It's a fun game now and can only get better with time as the bugs get ironed out. I definitely recommend this to anyone who has a creative imagination and wants to have big epic space dogfights.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Im loving this game!, i like to sit down in my planet look at the sky (which in this game is superb) and choose between thousands of stars the one i will go explore next, or mine, or just destroy it if i had a bad day at work XD.
Never have had a such sense of freedom in a game, you can do everything! from destroying planets,  build bases, ships or whatever you feel like wanting to create,  The game has its own rules which makes building more interesting, ie. to have the best power performance in your shiip you need to  put blocks in different specific ways etc.. so you do need to set up your own strategy when buiding something, and there are no limits you can build ships as big as planets if you feel like doing so.
Also the developer is (in my humble opinion) leading the game to the right direction, i would like see when the game is relased a bunch NPC factions, trading between themselves, securing their trading routes with armored ships, starting wars and more interactivity in that direction along with more brand new....BLOCKS !.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing (Currently in Pre-Alpha), the map is so intelligent, it is sorted by Solar Systems, then each system has a lot of sectors, so it's not hard to find places (though it can be due to the vastness of space). Even though the space in this game is not realistic (it's in the km distance ranges) it works 100% due to the way everything looks and feels. Jumping through space is freaking awesome. Designing ships is awesome.

IF I COULD ADD ONE THING TO THE GAME, IT WOULD BE THRUSTER TRAILS THAT CAN HAVE THEIR COLOR CHANGED WITH THE ROD LIGHTS (the same way you change bullets on weapon modules, place it in front of the barrel) =DD

If the trails were like 1-3 blocks in length, that would be awesome, and would add incentive to actually having thruster blocks in a visable part of your ship, instead of fake" thrusters that most people make with Crystal blocks to show glowing plasma / hot turbines. This works and makes a ship look great
date: but I would honestly love trails to see some distance / speed. It would also be helpful to finding other ships when they're moving fast (some servers have +speed mods). It would also be awesome if the trails extend for a very short period of time when a ship jumps
recommended: that way ships that stay behind can see a "thruster ghost" of all of the light left behind from the thrusters. :3\n\nAlso aminals. Not really super important
hoursPlayed: but it would be cool to see some actual life forms in the game aside from pirates and shops. :3 just saying\n\nBUY THIS GAME EARLY ACCESS
voteText: OR WAIT TILL RELEASE

09/11/2015  @ alpha v0-19485:

Nice project, with lot of potential. Very curious to see how all this will evolve.
Go for it if you want to help the game gettin' better you can already have a lot of fun with everithing that is currently available.

the things i m especially watching for in the incoming updates:

- Watching for grid overlap with docking, curently allow many many many sort of exploit.

- Ui improvment (mostly factories endless scrolling menu, a table with many component seeable & last entered amount would be preferred imho, actually it tend to make crafting with lot of different block really tedious, eventually single factory different component building queue will be appreciated at some point and/or factory production switch from [display]//logic circuit ; chat not real intuitive in it's current form, pop pup window over pop up window, tab and overlay are usually much more handy)

- Overall inter chunks Synchro (for logic stuff especially)

- something really need to be done about the nahhhh mine is bigger" kind of stuff

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I first started playing StarMade before it was on Steam, and before the planets were 3-dimensional, back in the days of simple planet mining and space station harvesting, I would have never expected the kind of leaps and bounds that have happened to this game. My personal reccomendation to anyone who likes spending their time really making stuff, is to get this game. It might seem complex at first, but with enough time anyone can learn it and if you don't think it's worth paying just yet, they have a free version on their website, along with what I believe to be the equally free demo here on Steam.

tldr: Minecraft in space is fun, and pirates kick ♥♥♥ when they can spawn the ships you build

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game so much, It's a little complex at the start though, but when you get used to how the mechanics work, It's the coolest experience ever. Building all type of ships, space stations, machines, hulls/armor, and a whole bunch of cosmetic blocks. You mine for resources and can refine them to create mesh and composite, which are the basic crafting items.

I don't even have the best computer, but I could run the game pretty well. The planets from far away kind of lag me, but when you get on them the lag stops.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTo sum up starmade, imagine an endless universe with no limits on anything (except small planet sizes but oh well) like minecraft block style, with more detail. You can build anything ontop of this you  can build up your own faction in a persistant (probs spelt that wrong) universe. want to create the federation from star trek and explore the galaxy in the uss enterprise? yup and you can probably build deep space 9. want to be a space pirate in a steam punk style pirate ship? yup, want to have an emperor class battleship and create the 40k imperial navy? that will take a while but yup. what you can imagine you can create, ive put 600 hours into this game, mostly offline creating ships and space stations to use online. with the new features they have added like rails and cargo this game is just great the only complaint i have is i would like to see larger planets, alot bigger. there really is nothing i can fault this game on, you really can do anything you want, the trailer doesnt do this game enough justice for the true scale of this game. belive me its awesome

Baue dein eigenes Schiff, Station oder Planetenbasis und besiegen deine Feinde.
Trette der Community bei und kämpfen mit oder gegen andere Spieler,  erstelle oder tritt einer Fraktion bei und baue dein eigenes Imperium.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a lot of time put into this game as you can see. I love this game. Yes it has many issues and a few settings you need to change so it will work well, but it is a great game once you work those out. Here's a list of the pros and cons.

-Pros
- Minecraft in space
- Endless creativity
- Completely destroy planets
- Incredible Multiplayer with factions and diplomacy

-Cons
- Eats RAM, need to change some settings so game will work properly
- My computer can't handle singleplayer so Multiplayer is my only option
- Crashes every now and then
- Mining planets will extremely lag or crash servers

I highly recommend buying this game if you love being able to build a ship to explore space, build a Titan and crush your enemies, or create a faction and conquer the galaxy with your friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OverviewAt its current state, I must recommend this game. But before you stop reading, there are a few things you should hear from me.

1. The tutorial is not very helpful.

This is the main reason I don't have many hours on this game. I played the tutorial over 3 times, and am still confused on many things. I have mostly been guided by the wiki.

2. This game is FREE right now.

Until the final release, you can get this game for free on their website. However, you will have to buy it once the game exits Early Access.

3. The sensitivity is VERY low.

I turned my mouse sensitivity, from my mouse, all the way up, and it was still hard to move. The only way to fix this is by going into options and adjusting the sensitivity from there.

Pros‣ Gigantic Universe
‣ Multiplayer
‣ Diverse Ship Building Combinations

Cons‣ Lacking Tutorial
‣ Poor Sensitivity Optimization

Final ThoughtsWhile this game may have a steep learning curve, it is very fun to play, and over time, it will become more fun the more you learn about it. There are countless things to do in StarMade that make it worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This truly is a great game. Sure, it's a little unpolised at the minute but it's so much more than a just a voxel game. You can't build a spaceship and have at it - your spaceship has to WORK.
Also, don't think that because this is voxel-based it'll run well on anything. On my old laptop with integrated graphics it averaged an impressive 12fps with all settings at their lowest possible. I'm looking forward to playing much more of it now that I've got my PC built.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game and just because it looks like Minecraft, it doesn't mean it sucks like most other games that look like Minecraft. Such as Minecraft for example! But thats a different game, this game has cool features while Minecraft is... Minecraft. StarMade is a space game where you run fly around space in your... hey... where's your ship? When you first spawn you ain't got jack ♥♥♥♥ other than some starter equipment for a tiny, tiny, tiny ship. But you do have 25,000 bucks to spend on equipment. Spend it wisely, and dont just die and lose it. While building, please for the love of god don't ♥♥♥♥ing press BACKSPACE. It will delete what ever you are currently holding in your hotbar. It says drop" but since this is space and all
date: space does you a favour and just eats it so you don't have to see junk everywhere. Neat right? Well so far the only things bad about this space builder is the clunky controls that take a while to get used to
hoursPlayed: dont forget the GRAPHIKS THAT SUK!!! The graphics aren't bad. They're blocky and why the ♥♥♥♥ does it matter? Some of the amazing things that everybody needs to know before buying is that 1. You can purchase a crew. 2. Singleplayer (should've already known that) 4. (because ♥♥♥♥ 3.) multiplayer. 5. You can create big spaceships. 666. There's space stations that could be even bigger than the space ship! 777 (won me the lotto!) Pirates and Storeowners to spice up the experience. 8. Easy to create servers. 9. SPAAAAAAAACE!!! And the big 10 inch ♥♥♥♥

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is fun as hell, and has amazing potential, but for the love of god work on optimising it!
I get a solid 40 fps at near max settings, only to drop to 1 fps near any planet.
I dropped the settings to dead minimum and it's stuck at 2-3 fps and my ship can't take off for no apparent reason.
Work on that, so that the game is actually playable, and it's a 9.5/10 easy. Currently, Im only willing to give it 7.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although its still early to write a review i am still going to make one.
Ive played this game alot, mostly before release on steam.
It has got alot in common with the Voxel,Sandbox,Openworld game Minecraft but it still is so different.
While most game-mechanics probably are subject to change, the concept of building your own spaceship likely will remain. Simply because to go and fight with your own creation is awsome.
The way this game is progressing and the way the Devs deal with the community is great.
I can only recommend this game to anyone who has a liking towards the Space and Sci-Fi genre.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI made a giant spaceship about 0.2 kilometers long.  It has rapid firing torpedoes and a nuke.  My broadsides will blast holes through lesser ships.  My point defense turrets can take down pirate ships with their combined fire power.  Even though I can one hit kill a pirate ship and drain it of its life, my biggest fear are damned space spiders.  Never will I board an abandoned space station without nuking the ♥♥♥♥ out of it.  Now I'm gonna go huddle near my reactor core as the screams of spiders echoes through the vast emptiness that surrounds me and my vessel.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Me and 2 others played this on a server for a while.  It's really fun, and has a lot of potential.  The building of ships is awesome but even beyond that you can build space stations and land bases.  Really almost anything you can think of.  Some of the features I found hard to use like the games own version of red stone.  The game uses logic modules that I found a bit rough but then I didn't spend a ton of time on it either.  Also the lag was bad, this could have been the server I was on but I have a feeling it's the size of the galaxy.  As people move further out and more and more is generated the game slows down.  Oh and that brings me to the final issue.  Space!  There is so much of it you almost never run into anyone.  If not for the chat you might as well play it alone.

All in all it's an awesome game that I have no regrets buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First I'd like to say, Ya'll are doing great.  I know its alpha, and i expect issues, and the one i have noticed thus far is how occasionally I will come across a station that is there, but i cant see it, and it acts as iff it is not there.  Shooting missles at it gets a pinpoint hit in the middle, and it seems i can blow them up.  However, when i log off as this is happenening, i cant log on the same server for days.

I know those stations are there, but something buggy is going on at the same time.

Great game, mechanics, future promise.  This one has it all and more than most of the alphas out there.  If this game, Space Engineers and Empyrion had a love child.  It would be the expectations of the entire Space Minecraft" fan group.  Just pop some fun pills and give that some thought.

I recommend this game to those who love building massive ships and stations

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you enjoy the freedom of designing your own ships while flying around space and exploring planets you will probably enjoy this game.

Pros:
-huge universe to explore.
-Intuitive in-game building system.
-Linking systems provided great customizability.
-good level of trade offs force design choices.

Cons:
-procedurally generated planets aren't that interesting.
-gathering resources can feel like a chore.
-galaxy feels very under-populated. Almost lifeless.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minecraft... in space!

While this is still in early access, there's already a lot of stuff you can build/program and the devs are adding to it regularly. The ingame universe is practically limitless and dotted with innumerable planets and space stations to explore, so even if you're not too keen on building there's still a lot to see here.

As of writing, you can check out StarMade with all current features for free, so there's no excuse to not at least give it a look.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoying this game so far had it for a longtime and found the controls really confusing and i set it aside. i was scrolling through my games collection and remebered this after a quick watch of the trailor on steam (love that music such a great
song). I just can't stop playing it i thought for me to learn it and focus it would be better to do singleplayer.

Which yes it was looked up some admin commands when pirates turned up and lagged the game out alot after learning some controls i actually find the quite easy to play now.

To me the game is a great mix of Eve online and minecraft. it runs really well on my couple of generations ago pc. I let it load up watch the FPS to see it stablize then play the game pretty much lag free apart from approaching planets to mine them. If i travel in space the game is always lag free.

Building spaceships is really exciting to me as you will spend many hours working out a ship design thats works best for your style of play. Then of course if you play multiplayer it's all about building bigger then all the other players which some ships i've seen are getting upto 6million blocks taking them weeks to months to finsih with very interesting designs and variety.Then you have logic blocks for well doing logic. watcvhing videos on youtube people have made semi automatic ships for mining which i am absolutly amazed people worked out. (planning on working on it myself).

I wish there were alot more players playing i think with a bigger community that put the effort in it could become as popular if not more then minecraft. the ideas are great and the game overall is to me excellent it just need some more to make it feel more alive, some fixes in lag for loading planets and some better ai in the ai block. Which are all things they addressing in the future from what i have been reading (dont quote me on it though).

overall atm 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm addicted. So many things to do, to understand, to master... A real feeling of progress in design, efficiency, power...

Starting from a 5 blocks ship, going up to 50, 500, 5 000, 50 000... Excellent build helper tools ingame. Excellent community creations to show you what is possible, and still everytime, someone manages to do something new.

Sure it has some bugs, some frustrations, some balance issues...

But it's so little compared to what Starmade has to offer. It's often compared to Minecraft. It's not Minecraft in Space.

It's so, so, much more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If Minecraft is a sandbox, StarMade is the beach. And instead of getting a shovel, you're given a bulldozer. The way the weapon system works is great - if this were in minecraft, it'd be like strapping 4 bows to your arms, but instead of arrows you shoot pickaxes to mine faster. And do you like that epic mansion you built in singleplayer? Why not save the blueprint and rebuild it in multiplayer? All you need are the resources. AMAZING. What's more, the game is free. FREE. Go and try it out, then pay for the game anyway because it's damn fun.

THESE DEVS CARE. Lots of updates, great community and massive potential. The game has a lot of great things in it, the core mechanics are solid and lots of different elements. Let's review some of the common comments:

Great multiplayer - valid (this game is built for sharing with friends or strangers)
Boring single player - mixed (there's not much to do" other than fight pirates
date: build spaceships and mine resources. There wasn't much to do in Minecraft in Beta either. Quests are coming.\nBugs - invalid (the game is free
hoursPlayed: and yeah it's an alpha)\n\nReal talk: you'll probably never build anything epic. You want to build the Enterprise? You won't. But you CAN download the blueprint. My only warning is that the game isn't optimised yet
voteText: and there are lag spikes even on recommended system requirements. Memory leaks are common in alphas and so I'm ok with this. Some funny bugs though
helpfulPercent: a trade guild convoy of about 5 ships crashed into a planet and was stuck. Dropped fps to about 1-5fps
votesHelpful: practically unplayable
votesTotal: but also hilarious. Would lag again."
votesFunny: January 15, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its funish

Pros:
Its original.
Ship building is way fun.
The weapons system on said ships is unique.
it's a charming game to play.
The new UI looks very nice and clean.

Cons:
Player controls are ridged and funky, theres no momentum in Zero-G.
ships roll WAY too quickly, to the point you cant rotate small ones to align with docking bays.
Tutorial is annoying and has numerous gramatical errors.

Minor nitpicks:
The mining decal on blocks will not reset if you imediately start on another block, I've gotten the grid to look like solid blue.
You start seeing the starlines at way too low speeds (Moving your character outside a ship makes them).
Planets are REALY REALY close.
The galaxy map is too uniform, stars should be in more random positions inside of the cubic sectors.

Conclusion:
It needs refining, early access is not an excuse for a half-baked product, stuff like movement should be perfected as soon in development as possible. I have faith that this will become a great game in time but it is a bit underwhelming at the moment, buy if you realy think you will love it
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game worth a nosey.

Comparible to Minecraft, but in space. With an insanely large galaxy (or multiple if you wish) to explore and create in.

The multiplayer is pretty solid as well, with a number of well populated servers.

Being early access there still needs to be quite a bit of polishing up, but with each update there has be very noticable optimization of performance. As well as tweaking elements of the game such as planet layouts and the UI to great effect.

If you are into creating insane battleships, slick fighters and gigantic space stations, whilst crafting from scratch on a galactic scale; I would recommend keeping your eye on this one!

Have a look at the demo to get a taster :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its funish

Pros:
Its original.
Ship building is way fun.
The weapons system on said ships is unique.
it's a charming game to play.
The new UI looks very nice and clean.

Cons:
Player controls are ridged and funky, theres no momentum in Zero-G.
ships roll WAY too quickly, to the point you cant rotate small ones to align with docking bays.
Tutorial is annoying and has numerous gramatical errors.

Minor nitpicks:
The mining decal on blocks will not reset if you imediately start on another block, I've gotten the grid to look like solid blue.
You start seeing the starlines at way too low speeds (Moving your character outside a ship makes them).
Planets are REALY REALY close.
The galaxy map is too uniform, stars should be in more random positions inside of the cubic sectors.

Conclusion:
It needs refining, early access is not an excuse for a half-baked product, stuff like movement should be perfected as soon in development as possible. I have faith that this will become a great game in time but it is a bit underwhelming at the moment, buy if you realy think you will love it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've owned this game for close to 2 years now (back before it was available through Steam). Updates have been frequent enough to keep me interested, but there is still a bit left to desire. It's an alpha-release and it's obvious sometimes that more features are needed. I enjoy the creative aspect more than battles, and the scale of constructs is mind-boggling sometimes.

I've had pleasant experiences with the community and other players - some of the ships and stations in-game were created by players and uploaded during contests. Unlike other Pre-Release games, you can get free access to this one (as of the date of this post), which goes to show the developers are more focused on the product that the profits.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt first I was skeptical of this game. It is an alpha after all, and I fully expected bugs and even some parts to not even be playable. I tried the demo, which is the full game btw. Then bought the game a couple hours later. And people please realize that this game is in an early stage. Bugs and changes will happen. It is very playable and very fun, even outright addicting. This game has very great potential. If you like the idea of designing your own ship, exploring, and then going out to battle in your newly constructed dreadknaught, you will like this game. 10/10. Now, I'm going back to building my dreadknaught.

Early Access Review

TL;DR

Demo is the full game right now. Download and play. Decide for yourself.

/TL;DR



Caution: If you're creative minded, you may lose more time than you realised. I keep going to sleep at 5AM, thinking it's about 1AM when I FINALLY check the clock.

For the massive scale constructor in all of us. Game can be played for free though you can buy it now cheaply before they scale the price for release and get patch support after release (demo won't be updated). Literally Early Access" I suppose.

Not sure what the hell a voxel is? Never played Minecraft?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voxel

So basically
date: this game is a giant sandbox where you do as you damn well please. Mine the materials
hoursPlayed: refine the materials...build an Imperial Star Destroyer?! You can be as imaginative as you want - build your ship in any way
voteText: shape or form that pleases you and hurts other people's eyes if you wish. Or as uncreative as you like - build famous ships straight out of sci-fi from X-Wings to the Enterprise to B-Wings to the Voyager
helpfulPercent: the Yamato
votesHelpful: the Sunrider*
votesTotal: the Galactica...the list goes on. Hell
votesFunny: someone's building a Death Star space station. You can do that too - then host a server
commentsCount: get friends to join and wait for the "That's no moon..." quotes. For the reference
column16: your character is a 1x2 figure. Now imagine the 10
column18:
000+ block ships some people have floating around. Yeah. Welcome to Starmade.

Currently no music in game. Might I recommend FTL: Faster Than Light's* soundtrack? xD

What I'd kill for:
- Assuming I haven't missed it
column19: the ability to move entire planes up and down. Think of the X-Wing's attack and speed modes. Yeah
column20: this would probably kill memory and likely will never happen
column21: but I can dream right?\n- Better optimized lighting. Preferably a gamma setting. Current lights are a serious drain
column22: especially in large numbers. Simplified lighting setting basically removes lighting altogether. (AFAIK
column23: devs have said this is on the todo list)\n- ...less confusion. Oh granted

column27: but there's no advanced tutorial. Good luck to you trying to figure out how docking or turrets work.\n- 'Destroy' option for inventory. Assuming I haven't missed this too
column28:
can only seem to drop blocks. Can't destroy them. The game will happily solve this based on a timer by removing things from memory after a certain time/distance.
- Control sensitivity options. It's beginning to annoy me that I can rarely (if ever) get my ship to be level with the hangar it's being constructed in. Can never seem to roll 'a bit' to the left or right to be level. >_>

*Check Steam's store for these games. Sunrider is a (free) Visual Novel. FTL: Faster Than Light is an indie...RTS/RPG/Roguelike mashup? Can't describe it properly

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very good game if you like minecraft, though space themed and more in depth. A little glitchy due to beta stages and can lag quite badly if building/encountering large ships or you play on a low spec system. New rail system makes docking much easier,and the possibilites for moveable objects (i.e, landing pads that move into hangars,elevators, soild doors, etc) is now immense. Turret system is a little more complicated but once again its gives more options for design and construction of turrets. All in all 8/10

Early Access Review

This is a great game!

If you want to build and fight with ships, this game will get you your fix!!

The update schedule isn't terribly fast (once a month, usually) but the updates they roll out are generally fairly significant. This game is still in development for sure but its come a loooong way!

The Dev's have promised us RP/Survival/Story elements this coming year - that is the game's current biggest weakness, so if done right, this could be really fantastic! Here's hoping!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where do I begin...
Honestly I don't like space games simply because they have great graphics but they don't let you build your ship block by block. You have to do it in presets that cost to much in-game money it starts feeling like the junk guy from Star Wars 64 racing game. This game lets you build ships, space colony ships, and even planets block by block. This game takes time to understand the fomula but if you love minecraft and space this game is for you. This is defenitly not for players looking for hardcore PVP and amazing graphics, but it is for those who are extremely creative or die hard fans of star trek, star wars, or star fox, hell just be a fan of stars period.

In my time I made my single player be about a woman whos possibly the last survivor of a space colony that blew up and she crashed landed on different planets then let my friends play it and see the story out. The game also lets you make factories so they build units and store them into a box while your out please note that going to far from your galaxy or logging off a server will pause the units being made" and you can make complicated systems using the in-game tools. Want an R2D2
recommended: want an arwing from StarFox you can make it. Seriously you can build like crazy here anything you want but I'm going to warn you about servers and enemies in a sec.\n\nServers can be really empty I mean even if theres 16 players online most are already in a faction or doing their own thing so if your like me and you made a peaceful little space bar/club and you advertise it
hoursPlayed: players might raid it or blow it up for fun. If you built a huge base on a planet far from everyone and even got rights to the planet dont be serprised if that server is down within a month of you playing. Servers either die off or restart everything due to updates. Personally what I did was test out a server
voteText: build a few things and add to it but not get emotionally invested in my creations. I also want to point out you can save all of your designs and copy/paste them in your game files! Lastly Enemies in the game are lock on killers. Seriously no sound as of yet to let you know your #$% is getting attacked and that motha@#$% gotta a cannon the size of godzillas dammmmmmn! Enemies lock on way to robotically and fast so when you see the sign [respawn] you realise what happened and cuss your screen off. BTW if your ship blows up that it... no more ship unless you saved the blueprints and build another one.\n\nIf your just starting the game a huge tip is to look for a server that gives you a lot of [credits] and has a high "mph" so you can learn to build and explore faster. Also if your completely new to the game I highly suggest looking for a quick tutorial video on youtube. The tutorial ingame is so wall of text you'd reread my reveiw 5 times and still wouldn't complian. Basically to sum up my review its a good #%^ game moth!@#$ buy this @#$%!!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a huge potential.

It's a merge of Space Engineers with Minecraft, a very great combination.

You can make your ships ( even the interiors ) and explore planets and gather resources from them.
You can create factions, edit it in a vast roll of options.
Create Stations and fleets.
Tons os servers.

This game is designed to be played online, if you are a single player, than this game might get boring after a few days.

8/10 for an early game.

Just waiting for it to be finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome and has a ton of potential, but it is clearly lacking a ton of features.

Now of course you can say that it is an early access game. However, the team of developers is small and despite trying to keep to a two weekly release schedule of updates, they don't make it as often as they make it. In fact, they haven't released anything in a month and the last few updates only consistent of small bugfixes and the updates before that consistent of a completely buggy Fleet" system that makes my ships rubberband like crazy and has extreme limitations. Schine claimed to be done with the fleet system over the course of several updates
date: but this is ridiculous.\n\nI could wholeheartedly recommed this game if it had regular updates and felt like it comes closer to at least the beta (after being years in the alpha)
hoursPlayed: you are better off not buying it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starmade is a fantastic game. I've played it for hundreds of hours for free, when I found it in 2013. Since then, it's only gotten better and better. After a very long hiatus from the game, I've come back to see so many wonerful features added and ironed out, making this a wonderful experience to discover.

Thousands of planets, asteroids, and things to do.

Giant ships, limited only by your imagination (and CPU specs, I suppose).

Dedicated servers meaning worlds for you to play in that you actually matter to.

There's so much to like about this early access title, and I'm betting we have a lot more to look forward to.

Buy it if you've played Minecraft and thought I wonder what it would be like if I could go to space"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has been slowly getting better and better, the rail system added ALOT of new fun possibilities. It's VERY early beta/alpha and I don't expect much of it right now. But I have high hopes of this game. The in-depth system's and territory system couple lead to a massive community when given the chance (MMO maybe?)

-Right now the weapon's just don't feel right and you don't feel like you have the power to wreak havoc upon a ship or destroy it quickly with major caliber weapons. That being said this game needs a quick overhaul on some graphics and some music (music is something I think every game needs and it's a lil bland without it)

-There are some bugs that don't help the game out, like when I logout inside a ship that ship disappears

At this point I don't have much to say about the game and I wouldn't recommend it. But I've seen alot of promising things and I'd defiantly keep a eye on it ;)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game was good up until they added the Personal Block Limiting, This has 100% killed immersion into this game where as unlimited block storage space in your personal inventory made it to where if you where into a deep building project you can keep going and going NOW you cant, I am dissapointed fully in this changed, newtonian method, This is a whole new issue itself you loose diversity of flight controle now and if you dc your ship is GONE, I remember without Newtonian that a ship can turn on a dime and move faster and stop faster aswell, with newtonian method in place you ship has just WAY to much drag now and when you wana stop YOU CANT based on the mass of your ship and engins....I clocked in 582 hours on this game then this change comes along and kills me fully, I am highly recomending that this be removed or its just 1 less person playing maybe even many more.... 10/10 down to 7/10,. I cant get back into this game and have fun and be happy any longer :C

cons:

- terrible default key bindings
- the 'controls' section of the settings doesn't show all controls.
- terribly dull GUIs
- bland color scheme
- seizure inducing flashes of light
- the dialogue is impeccable
- unnecessarily complicated inventory

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey, I understand that this Intel thing is a hard problem for them to fix, but it is not impossible like they want you to believe. The problem is they created the game from the ground up without Intel cards in mind, resulting in a game that is broken for many people. Shame on them for selling people a game that people had to bend over backwards just to get it to start up, and for not even mentioning the problem until after we bought it. A game should be sold so that people can run it WITHOUT having to waste time fixing it to run, and if not, they should at least inform you of the problem before you buy it. Stop expecting people to bend over backwards to run your game and just fix it yourselves. I don't care if you have to rebuild it from the ground up, I payed money for this game and I have been hoping that it will eventually work so long that I can no longer get a refund. JUST FIX IT!!!

This is like selling a game on an iphone, and then telling them that it doesn't work on their device AFTER they buy it. The only difference is that Apple usually forces the developer to stop ripping iphone users off and fix the problem themselves.

You want my advice? Buy Minecraft while it's on sale, get a free space mod. It may not be as good, but at least it will work as soon as you install it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is confusing.  You will not know what to do when you first turn the game on & it will take you some time (hours or longer) to figure out exactly how to do things.

Also, ignore the 0.1 hours played since I've not been playing the game through Steam.

The game starts you out near a shop in the middle of space.  The tutorial broke for me so I couldn't use it.  I had to figure out everything by experimentation & through guides online.

The first thing you need to do is build a ship & you have no idea how to do it.  I spent 4 hours figuring out how to build a ship with some long video showing me only to have it vaporize once I went into a warp.  Not only did I just waste 4 hours of my time I ended up pennyless with no ship stranded at the starting area.  After a lot of frustration I ended up making a smaller ship after selling what little materials I had left & went to my first planet which was kind of cool in a way.  The planets aren't really planets in a sense.  More like, several pieces with their own gravity stuck together.  If you walk around you'll see dead drops & if you jump over the drop you'll be pulled down by the other sides gravity.  Sort of like a janky Super Mario Galaxy.  Only half the planet had any atmosphere & it was always the half facing the sun which I didn't understand why they did this until I realized the side with atmosphere is supposed to be daytime while the space sky is night.  I guess it works but it's wierd looking up & seeing half day/night skies.

Later, I relogged in to find my ship was gone.  Then as I searched around for it I realized it had spawned in the middle of the planet I logged out of which is kind of funny.  Here's a video of the experience.

https://youtu.be/Zp4JUkF5_1E

Been playing the game a bit more & harvesting asteroids with a new ship I made which seems to be the easiest way to make money.  Harvest & then sell what you gather.  Managed to build myself a half decent ship as well even though it's unfinished.  The whole thing still rather confusing.  I don't really know what I need to get hyperdrive working properly so my ship doesn't vaporize. I'm probably not gonna be trying that again for a while. Exploring that far away might not be worth it yet anyways.

This game also has performance issues.  Being an Alpha build I guess that is to be expected because the game runs badly & locks up on me at random moments.  Usually it locks up during the first loading sequence or when I shoot something for the first time.  If you're running a lower end machine I really don't recommend running anything on high settings.  I tried having shadows on High & it dropped my FPS down to single digits.

If you do decide to buy it, do it to either support the devs or to see it through it's development cycle.  If you do plan on playing this game expect to spend several hours trying to figure out how to do anything because it's currently very confusing.  Hopefully the tutorial won't break for you like it did for me.  There's a lot of potential here & I'll probably end up playing this game more in the future & when it gets better overall.
